review: Just got this today... shipped via usps and delivered on a Sunday!  So far I am crazy about this tablet. It is such a value at this price.  With the year of office 365 being $70, this thing is like 30 bucks.  At this early point, I would recommend this tablet to everyone.

The prices of Windows devices continue to plunge! HP has just released this new 7 inch tablet that runs the full version of Windows 8.1. Build quality for the price is surprisingly good. HP managed to get a 7 inch IPS display built into the tablet and it feels solid overall. Performance is actually pretty decent. It has a quad core Intel Atom processor that delivers about the same performance as other Atom based PCs. It is hindered by only having one gigabyte of memory, so there will be a limit to how much multitasking the machine can handle without slowing down. When running one application at time the machine feels as good as some of the inexpensive Atom based laptops I've looked at recently. Gaming performance is lacking for modern games (mostly due to the small amount of available RAM) but older games and casual mobile games should work fine. The Stream 7 lacks an external video port, so it's not easy to use the tablet on a larger display. It is possible to transmit the display wirelessly to a Miracast device, but the output has a lot of latency and it won't go beyond its native 1280x800 resolution. The charging port is OTG compatible, so it might be possible to use a USB video device with it. Yes it has limitations - both in its available memory and external display capabilities. But Compare this to any other $99 tablet out there and it's exceptionally good - especially given how well it runs the full version of Windows 8.1 DISCLOSURE - I purchased this tablet with my own funds

This is perhaps one of my most disappointing purchases in the last several years.  This tablet failed to live up to expectations for several reasons:

1) Poor wifi connectivity: although I have used the device with a number of different access points while owning it, it's clear that the connectivity issues are specific to the device.  If the tablet goes to sleep, upon waking, you have to disable and re-enable wifi on the device before it will reconnect.  Sometimes this is insufficient.  It has got to the point that it's frankly just easier to reboot the darn thing every time you want to use it.

2) Poor customer support from HP: I reached out to HP about the wifi issues with the device and they provided very little help... they helped me to reinstall the driver for the wifi (which I had already done, twice, and told them as much) and otherwise showed no real interest in helping. they seem to have relegated support to owners trying to help each other out on their support site.

3) Computing power too limited: Simply put, the device is underpowered.  Yes, it was a cheap device, but it runs applications so slowly that you're going to regret the purchase at the price point.  For instance, the mail and calendar application from Microsoft repeatedly crashes during use.  If you are looking at a weather map you find that it takes a long time for any weather animations to make progress.

4) Poor battery life: I blame both the tablet itself and Windows for this.  The Windows power options are not well configured to encourage battery life on devices with small capacity batteries because it's difficult to set sleep and hibernation states.  Unlike other phones and tablets I have owned Windows does not seem to allow for wifi to run properly to keep getting things like email updates when the device is sleeping (without significant battery drain).  It's possible that this problem is related to the wifi problems I encounter with this device, but none-the-less, other devices manage battery much better.  The number of times at the outset I grabbed the tablet after a few hours to do something only to find that the battery level was critical so the device would not power on was incredible.

I had hoped that the Windows 10 update would help to improve this device, but alas it hasn't helped with most of these issues.  Indeed, installing it was an ordeal because of the wifi connectivity problems... ultimately I had to resort to using a USB adapter to plug a USB key into the device after loading windows onto it from another computer.

Overall I am extremely disappointed in this device -- it has caused nothing but frustration for me.  On a recent trip I literally said to my wife "I should throw this thing into the hot-tub so I won't feel so guilty about getting rid of it."  Save your money and get something else.

I have had this tablet now for several months.  There are things I love about it and things I hate about it.  Prior to switching to a Windows tablet, I was using an Android tablet (a Kindle with a CM Rom, if that means anything to you).  I switched to a Windows tablet because I liked the idea of having a full Windows OS at my disposal.  Along the way I have encountered several pros and cons from taking such an approach.

First  the tablet comes with Windows 8.1, but is easily upgradeable to Windows 10.  A few drivers need to be updated, but they're relatively easy to come by.  Whether you run it with Windows 10 or Windows 8.1, youll need driver updates right away  most notably the Wifi driver and the video driver, which are problematic out of the box.

There is a lot of flex on the back cover, due to a significant amount of space between the non-removable battery and SD-Card slot and the removable cover.  This makes the device thicker than necessary, as well as contributes to a flimsy feel.

Having a full Windows tablet is nice  in theory.  It does run 32bit apps very well, and having a full Office installation at your disposal is very nice.  However, the screen is really too small for any real productivity, and a full-sized keyboard and mouse are needed if you plan to make use of the office applications.  The on-screen keyboard is absolutely terrible on Windows, with no swype-style options available.  Its 100 percent hunt and peck.

The Windows app store is also terrible.  Theyre *very* slowly adding apps, but there are not nearly enough to give Windows any kind of edge over Android.  (This is coming from a Windows fan, by the way).

The price is good, but again, doesnt hold any benefits over a decent Android tablet.  Overall, if I was to purchase again, I would definitely go with Android.

One plus is that no third party software or bloatware is included on the tablet.  Probably because the hard drive would be completely full if it was.

Now for the technical impressions:

The quad-core 32 bit Bay Trail processor is very nice.  It is capable of running Windows 8.1 or 10 very smoothly.  Unfortunately, the RAM is far too low for any kind of multitasking or any heavy program.  Even the app store restricts apps from this tablet due to having only 1GB of available RAM.  Webpages load slowly, programs crash, etc., as a result of the lower RAM.

A 7 screen is good for most tablets, but if you're using Windows 10 outside of Tablet mode, serious resolution modifications are needed in order to make the screen usable.  Font sizes need to be increased, for example.  The screen resolution (1200 x 800) is also weak.  It is acceptably bright for indoor use, but weak for outdoor use.  Black levels are horrible, severely lacking compared to other similarly priced tablets.  Likewise, and unsurprisingly, contrast is also terrible in comparison to other similarly priced tablets.  If image quality is a priority, this is not the tablet for you.  But honestly, that was probably a given by the resolution alone.

32GB of storage is far too small, also.  About half of that is usable, and fills very quickly.  Initially, apps could not be installed on the SD card, but this has very recently changed.

Battery life is acceptable, at about 4 hours (with low brightness and settings, it can be stretched to 5)  but this could definitely be better, too, as other tablets of this size and weight stretch to 6 or 8 hours.  Charge time is just over 2 hours from 0% to 100%.

The Windows 10 update is definitely worthwhile.  It adds tablet functions that are valuable (although sometimes admittedly glitchy), and the OS runs more smoothly than Windows 8.1

Both front and rear cameras are a joke.  I don't know why theyd even bother to put a 2MP rear camera on the device, and the 0.3MP camera on the front is barely Skype-worthy.  Neither camera has any kind of auto-focus, and I suspect that the rear camera is probably the same kind that would normally be used on the front of a higher end phone ore tablet.

Closing thoughts:

Office is now available on Android.  Cheaper, higher-end Android tablets are readily available.  In my opinion, unless you have something that absolutely needs to be able to run x86 apps, avoid Windows tablets.  Windows on a tablet has far more cons than pros.

For this tablet specifically:  For $100, you're getting something function, but not something great.  Its a good tablet if your expectations are low, but otherwise, it is just not worth it.  There are much better options out there.  If I had it to do over again, I would buy a previous model, discounted Nexus 7.  I think Id be a lot happier with it than I am with this device.

I returned this item after finding this out and seeing hundreds of users on the HP forums with not a fix in sight, tried new audio drivers, updating to windows 10, and updating the bios.

It worked well under Windows 8.1, but under Windows 10, it's a poorly considered mess, that just generally doesn't work. If you're trying to use your included Office 365 subscription with it, I'd suggest you not bother moving to 10. The subscription includes 1TB of storage. That's 1024GB of data. The tablet has 32GB of data. On Windows 8.1, OneDrive files are on OneDrive, but can be made available offline, and appear in all file selection dialogs. On Windows 10, OneDrive files are synced to the device. That means the files on OneDrive have to also be on the tiny 32GB of storage on the tablet for them to be accessible to applications. This changes 32GB of storage from practical to impractical.

I cried a little bit when manufacturers stopped producing Palmtops, the tiny little laptop-ish sort of affairs that used to be pretty commonplace among nerds and business travelers before laptops were cheap or light, and before your cellphone was also your email platform. I've searched far and wide for something that suited my delicate, lady-like fingers and my penchant for getting stuff done on long commutes without carrying a 10lb bag. I scoffed at tablets like the ipad which were so gimped all I ever saw a businessman do with one is play candy crush or some other embarrassing minigame on the ferry to work. I own the Stream 11, which is HP's super cheap ultralight chromebooky thing. It's great, but carrying whatever book I was reading was getting old, so I started looking at eReaders.

I was about 2 clicks from owning the new $50 kindle, until I saw this in the suggestions. I'd previously brushed it off as 'just another tablet', but then I did some thinking. Win10 has the Kindle app, a full office suite, a big-boy browser that will let me install adblock, and most importantly, a full Windows install that can run the Citrix app I need to connect to my office PC. Now for 90% of my commutes I can ditch both the book I would normally carry, and the HP netbook. People are quick to tell me I can't possibly get any work done on a 7" screen with a 7" keyboard case, but it's surprisingly effective. The fact that its a very dense (BRIGHT!) IPS means even small text in my terminal windows is easy to read.

People have rated the Kindle app for win10 poorly, but it does do the basics pretty well and I've been enjoying it in spite of the insanely nitpicky things people seem to complain about. In a pinch, I can fire up a full-on, native SSH client or my Citrix gateway and get some work done right away. In terms of performance, it's not going to break records, but I routinely have a web browser, the kindle app, and SSH going simultaneously and rarely hit any choppiness. On my first boot I was prompted for a win10 upgrade which I gleefully took, because Win10 is a major step forward. I didn't even realize all of the gesture controls at first, which make it an amazingly fluid experience. The downside is that a Win10 tablet has all of the desktop programs you love, but fewer of the 'App store' apps you need. An iPad/Android tab is the exact opposite. More often than not I'm more frustrated by having to use a gimped iOS version of my favorite program than not being able to find a certain mobile app, since most mobile apps generally prove to be crap.

The build quality isn't too bad, considering you can score one for $99, it's as well built as any average Windows laptop you'd buy. Apple is in a league of its own for build quality, so no, don't expect a unibody aluminum masterpiece with chamfered bezels for 1/6th the price. If I drop it off a subway platform, it might ruin about 2 hours out of my day before I got over it. When it's obsolete in a few years, I won't be mad at all. Enjoy paying as much as this thing costs for your applecare plan!

I bought this tablet (and wanted to keep) but became concerned about some performance issues.  I purchased via the Microsoft online store.  Return within 30day return period was relatively pain free

Pros

At $149 ($30 cheaper than HP) for a real computer a decent buy.

1. Much smaller and lighter than a laptop for travelling.
2. Leverage the T-Mobile capability when Wifi was unavailable.
3. Load a few apps and games.
4. A real computer with a file manager, micro USB for file transfer.
5. A cheap guinea pig device to upgrade to free Win 10 and try it out to reduce aggravation before I jump in with both feet to upgrade my laptop.
6.  Maybe stream shows or display tablet screen to my TV.
7.  32GB storage expandable to 64GB via micro SD.

Cons

1. Weak Wi-Fi reception  which was an annoyance. I would have had to buy a Wi-Fi range extender whereas no other devices I own have any problem with Wi-Fi reception in same location.

2. Tablet sometimes froze while trying to stream video wirelessly to TV using Microsoft Wireless display adapter.

3. Not sure why but if I was logged on as one standard user, turned off all radios (Wi-Fi, Cellular), shut down, rebooted and  tried to logon as a different standard user the Stream would return a message Device is offline, logon as prior user message.

4. Tablet is not MHL capable (MHL micro usb/HDMI cable to TV would not work).  I contacted HP before purchase.  First HP support rep said it was MHL capable.  I ordered MHL cable after placing tablet order.  Found out from second HP support rep Stream 8 is Not MHL capable.

5. MS App Store Implementation - Microsofts app store implementation is dumb (I am not talking about number of apps available).  In order to download apps you must have a Microsoft account locally installed on the Stream 8.  So when you are using apps you are logged on to app store (unless app can be used with Wi-Fi and Cellular turned off).  This is idiotic.  If you want to install an app you should merely be able to login to app store, download app, and log out.  Also  app is available for only the MS account on Stream 8 it was downloaded to and cannot be shared with any other user accounts on device.  I found out after the fact customers have complained about this MS app store implementation in forums for several years.

6. Cant use 32GB Micro SD storage to store apps or store downloaded maps for a map app such as HERE maps.

7.  OS  Microsoft Answer Desk - I was somewhat disappointed in Microsoft Answer Desk (they were ok if Windows 8.1 questions did not go beyond their script) but get beyond their scope and it was Well have to get you to paid support.  It was interesting when they sent follow up emails regarding a question discussed in a chat with a link to the answer desk indicating if I wanted to discuss the issue again with the same support rep just click on the link, but in reality it was impossible to reach the same support rep to discuss instructions the rep had previously provided.

I use this as a second tablet only. The good: expandable storage; runs Windows 8.1 apps, comes with cloud storage and Office 365, can run my client's VPN on this for work emergencies without lugging around my big laptop. Can pick up weak WiFi signals better than other devices.

The bad: the Windows OS just isn't great on this small screen. The keyboard is tiny so it is difficult to enter passwords, etc. Battery life is poor unless I keep this in airplane mode.

A lot of things that has been said about that tablet.
I just wanted to point out some aspects of my experience that are not matching the previous reviews:

a) Power drag on Idle: many report a high-powered drag on idle and are recommending for example to set the volume to zero and activate airplane mode in order to prevent short battery life on idle. I didn't do that and still have more than 50% battery after two full days idle. The only thing that I've done is to disable live information on all tiles of the modern desktop (which I don't really use by the way). I also have performed all the updates which appear to have included a new audio driver, so turning the volume to 0 is not necessarily any more.

b) Poor headset audio: I really can't complain I am using a Sennheiser headset on it and it really delivers a gorgeous quality...

c) Limitation to 125% on text size:
Out of the box, you can only increase the text size to 125% which is still unusable for that resolution on 7 inches.
I have finally found out a small hack to remove that limitation: change in the registry HKEY_CURRENT_USER/Control Panel/Desktop/Win8DpiScaling and set that value to "1".
Then you will be able to set the text size to 150% which is the only way to get the Windows desktop halfway usable without a mouse.

d) Operation beside a regular desktop: I really recommend the open source software "Synergy". With this free software you will be able to share seamlessly your keyboard and mouse between the screens of your desktop and your Stream 7 and even easily cut and paste between them. That is absolutely awesome! And free...

e) Last, but not least: get a good headphone with a noise cancellation microphone and make yourself familiar with the dictation abilities of Windows 8. It is not like iOS or Android: the dictation software of Windows 8 works fully autonomously: you don't need an Internet connection to dictate and it does not phone "home" everything you are saying. You will never want to enter text manually any more...

f) A small caveat: on one side it can run pretty every Windows program, on the other side the scope of Windows phone applications that run on that Tablet is pretty restricted. You need so-called "universal apps" to run on an Intel X86 based hardware. Those are not that common. Almost 80% of the "modern" applications written for Windows Phone won't run on that tablet...

The support from Microsoft for the 8.1 op. sys. leaves a very great deal to be desired. The device itself is serviceable, however, the screen-orientation-change feature is too sensitive, the VOLUME nearly inaudible from most sites, at 100%, and the user-friendliness, via Windows 8.1 is simply awful. I'd rather have ANY OP SYS, in future, than Windows (8.1).  It was an affordable, hopefully of short-duration, bridge to a better choice in future.

A family member wanted to give me a gift, and I chose Stream 8 (came directly from HP, but the same model that is sold here). I wanted to have a portable entertainment for kids and an occasional laptop replacement to work away from my office. Be careful what you wish for!
1. Appearance. It looks like most other tablets: black. The back panel is made of soft plastic and is easy to scratch. It has to be pried open by force to reach SIM and microSD, and I worry that it will break easily.
2. Wireless. It can receive Bluetooth, WiFi and GPS signals. When compared to a dedicated GPS unit and with my smart phone, Stream 8 took longer to acquire coordinates and calculate routes (all 3 devices were next to each other). Keep in mind that GPS navigation needs maps. You can either get them like your smartphone does (e.g. over 4G; this would need a lot of data transferred) or like a conventional GPS unit does (this would take a lot of room on your hard drive, if you can find them).
3. OS. Everything that you heard about Windows 8 is true. It is only a bit less annoying when you have a touchscreen. On the other hand, desktop interface and desktop-oriented programs are much harder to control by touch alone. For example, pinch-zoom is often not supported.
4. Performance. The device appears severely underpowered. It has the computing power and RAM of a common smartphone, but has to run a heavy OS. The unit often freezes or lags while responding to commands, loading web pages or performing other tasks. For a long time I had nothing but a couple of Microsoft programs on it, and it looked like it was struggling even with Minesweeper. It needs the same antivirus protection as any other Windows computer, but running a good antivirus program becomes a big burden for it. I wanted Windows functionality, but cannot fully take advantage of it.
5. Preinstalled programs. It comes with a cloud-oriented version of Office. Seems reasonable because of scarce local storage, but needs constant Internet connection and a lot of data transfer. Not practical for me. It also has an HP application, which is supposed to keep you updated about new drivers, etc. It seems buggy. At one point, it took me through countless consecutive rounds of installing the same BIOS update. At another, it was telling me to buy a memory upgrade, which wouldnt fit this unit.
6. Ports. There is only one microUSB 2.0. This is really pathetic. I understand that this is an OTG port, but to fully use it you need to carry a bag of adaptors. Charging while using a peripheral is annoyingly complicated. And all the adaptors add up costs. Even cell phones often come with separate HDMI ports, while many tablets have 2 USBs. Not to mention that modern devices come with a much faster USB 3.
7. Free 4G. This was the decisive factor for me to choose this model. I hoped that it would outweigh any drawbacks. It seems to me that HP was selling the units without proper arrangements with T-Mobile. When I just got the unit and followed the instructions, I couldn't connect to 4G. After two days of trying, I contacted T-Mobile and spent hours on the phone with them.  The reps appeared oblivious to any special deals with HP, but tried hard to sign me up for various paid plans. With no luck there, I continued my quest by contacting HP. That also took some time, but, finally, there was a rep who knew what I was talking about. We ended up having a conference call with T-Mobile, whose rep finally acknowledged the deal. It took quite some time to set up a new account. I was told that I will get a temporary allowance of data, but in a week everything will be fixed permanently.  Ten days later  no permanent fix. After another Odyssey through T-Mobile customer service, I was given another temporary allowance, to become permanent in a month. It did, after another lengthy call.  So, it took me many hours of effort and 1.5 months of wait to make sure that the advertised deal is honored.  Hardly worth the small amount of free data. My plight is not unique: HP customer forum has plenty of similar stories.
Overall, inferior features and difficulties in setting up free 4G make me give it a low score.
PS. It is very unhelpful for Amazon to bunch together reviews and ratings for different models of Stream.  These are different products, with different features and different expectations.

Just two pieces of advice:
1. Use Windows Explorer to get the free Microsoft Office.
I tried with Chrome and Firefox neither worked. Spent more than a couple of hours with both HP and Microsoft assistants trying to sort the problem out. No luck. I'm usually a heavy Chrome user, it was my default browser. Tried using Firefox, my (previously) second favorite, no luck either.

1.1 You can install Microsoft Office on another computer.
If you have another computer with the same Microsoft account you can note the URL when claiming the Microsoft Office upgrade and input it in another computer.
My laptop now runs the 1 year free Microsoft upgrade. Remember the upgrade is for one PC, so my HP Slate 7 doesn't have Microsoft Office.

2. Update the graphics driver.
Go to the Intel site and search for the latest drivers.
The popup box that Intel had when it was time to click install wasn't user friendly. I couldn't drag the box in either portrait or landscape. The whole box couldn't fit on the screen in either orientation. Eventually I connected a mouse and was able to click and hold to drag the box and access the install button on the far right bottom of the box. I did try doing this by touch, but it didn't work. That exercise was frustrating. I blame Intel for that.
An alternative would be to note the driver's version, do an internet search or search within the Intel site, get another link and download it from there. A final alternative would be to download it on another computer and transfer it to the HP Slate 7.
Why upgrade the driver? It helps with the screen mirroring (Miracast).
Just in case you don't know about this, if you have a compatible device you can project (mirror) one screen on another. I project movies and YouTube videos when my friends come over onto my smart TV. Remember it projects exactly what you see on the tablet's screen.

For the HP slate 7 Internet explorer is my choice browser. It runs smoothly and has pinch and zoom.
I use Chrome on my laptop 80% of the time. But on the Slate 7 Chrome is slow. My Firefox has the same extensions as Chrome (except Hangouts) but runs better. I tried running Chrome in Windows 8 mode, that didn't help either. Even with Hangouts disabled Chrome runs slowly so I uninstalled Chrome. Firefox is the choice browser for sites where Ad Block is needed.

I also purchased a 2.0 female to female adapter to connect a memory stick or Bluetooth mouse/keyboard. That's useful, I recommend getting that.

If you're not running intensive programs and you want value for your dollar then this is the tablet for you, HP Slate 7.

You can't beat a full windows tablet for 99 dollars, but keep your expectations in check. I am mainly using this for transferring music files from a Galaxy Note 3 and web surfing. This is not something you would want to use with resource hungry programs or games. I have come across some stutter and lag, as well as some touch input issues, but nothing overwhelming. The bluetooth is kind of touchy and I have had trouble keeping my phone connected. Oh, and it is not the exact size of a Galaxy Note 3, unlike what a reviewer said. It easily dwarfs a GN3, but is a small and cute form factor.

Helpful notes: If you want to receive bluetooth files you must go to desktop. On the right side press the arrow going up and you will see a set of icons. Press the bluetooth icon. Select receive or send a file. Make sure whatever you are syncing with has already established bluetooth service. Pick your file, and share. DO NOT let the screen go to sleep you will lose progress.

Sidebar menu: Swiping to left bring up a list of recently used apps. If in portrait mode, all apps seem to be full screen. In landscape mode they can become split screen, and you can adjust how much of the screen it can take up. Just select whatever app you want and slide it across the screen: some apps however are full screen only.
Swiping from right with bring up PC settings and other info. If you want to turn on bluetooth you have to go PC settings, but you will still have to go to desktop to send or receive files. You can also get to the control panel from here.

StartScreen: If you familiar with Windows phone or a Zune HD you now about live tiles. You can arrange them how you want or add programs. You can swipe down a level to see a complete list of all apps and Windows progams. I suggest pinning the task manager to the startscreen because it is the only way you can kill apps and programs, because there is no universal back button.

IE: there seem to be two versions of the Internet Explorer. The desktop version, which is less touch optimized, and the Metro version at the start screen which was thought of with touch input in mind. I suggest the Metro version which is less frustrating. It is much more touch intuitive.

Overview: I find the HP Stream 7 to be a quite handy device. It is great if you are on a budget and looking for a servicable PC. This is not a smartphone and you should not look for the same experience as an Android or IOS device. It is also not a PC powerhouse, but you can do a little serious work on it. The only problem I find with it is that Microsoft seems to be having issues marrying the Metro and desktop elements. There is to much going back and forth to use different services. Metro is nice and refreshing, but you can only do any serious work with the desktop. If they can get Metro as useful as the desktop, the they will have something great or their hands. I got this because I needed a PC experience for cheap and wanted a tablet. As much as I like Android, I did not want the same experience as I can get on my phone. I had a windows phone in the past, while I liked the platform, I had a few Android programs I was chained to and switched back. I have also owned a Zune 30 and a Zune HD which were fantastic devices, which birthed the Metro aesthetic, which I love very much. So this is perfect for me. If you want the same experience as a smartphone, look elsewhere. If you need a spec monster top of the line PC experience, get something else. If you want a functional computing device that can handle a few serious things and can handle your entertainment needs check this out. It only 99 dollars folks, so don't expect the world, but it still a great value.

EDIT: Make sure you install updates to get the bluetooth functionality. You can pin app to taskbar from startscreen, long press any tile and you get a set of options: pin to taskbar/start, uninstall and resize.

Pros:
- Feels good in hand, good size for general tablet use, browsing, Youtube etc.
- Good Build Quality, nice use of materials.
- Pleasant screen, excellent brightness and clarity.
- Responsive touch screen, good accuracy.
- Very well priced.
- Good internal storage space, although Windows takes up a hefty amount.
- Full year of Office 365 with Signature edition.
- Window's in general is fairly robust and can be fiddled with more than Apple/Android. Point to add: If you are tech minded and willing to work through software/hardware issues then you will have no problem. If you want a pick-up and go tab with little to no upkeep, I'd look elsewhere (Android/Apple).

Cons:
- Signature edition does not work out of box, at all. Mine arrived with NO drivers installed what-so-ever and no way of installing them without a MicroSD card or Micro USB OTG cable. Neither of which are supplied.
- Frequent WiFi issues. Connection drops or becomes limited with incorrect updates or drivers. Still to be resolved.
- No HDMI out. Video out can be achieved through wireless media applications, such as Serviio.
- Window's store is sparse (Not HP's fault) and popular apps are often not available (Instagram, Youtube etc). Hopefully this will improve.
- No other native browser supported (Chrome, Firefox, Opera etc.) and to top it off Bing is IE's default search engine and is not changeable.
- Battery capacity is not the best but can be cared for by switching off Bluetooth/Wifi etc.
- Low on the RAM side but run's applications fairly well.

All in all, for the price I paid, a very good tab. Falls short on out-of-box usability and additional features.

A 7 inch tablet is a strange bird these days, with 6 inch smart phones and 8 inch "mini" tablets.  However, 7 is a great size for those of us who have smaller-screen smartphones (in my case, GS4) to serve as a companion tablet.  I also own a Lenovo S8-50 tablet which, while great, would not accept exFAT formatted microSDHC cards.  Given that most 1080p MP4 movies can run >4GB, this was a problem as my collection of videos could only be viewed streaming.  This also eliminated the Kindle series tablets, so I was looking for a Windows compatible media player, and the Stream 7 caught my eye.

My main use for this tablet is watching video - streaming (Netflix, HBO, FX) and off microSD (Handbrake conversions) at the gym and on a plane.  Yes it comes with a 1-year sub to Office 365 personal, but I already have a 365 University account, and this wasn't of use to me (I copied the key code just in case I needed it for a friend's computer).  Besides, anyone who thinks they are going to work Office apps on a 7 inch screen either have really good vision, or are masochists.

The Stream isn't the first time I have used a Win8.1 tablet - I also have an original Surface (which is a tad too large to prop up on the treadmill at the gym), so I'm familiar with the limitations of Windows 8.1 RT.  With those expectations, even though the Stream 7 runs "Windows 8.1 with Bing" I did not plan on running legacy and desktop apps with it.  In fact, other than for system maintenance, the desktop isn't that helpful anyway.

I won't bore you with specs as you can find them in the description.  I will tell you that the real world feel is different.  While most 7 to 8-inch tablets are lightweight, this one weighs as much as a full blown iPad 4.  In fact, the Stream 7 is almost twice as heavy as the android-based HP 7 inch tablet.  The screen is crisper than the Surface - to be expected, they have similar resolutions but the screen is much smaller (increased pixel density) so movies look much better on it.  Even my SD video conversion look better on the smaller screen.  The screen is bright but, as expected, will wash out in sunlight.

Sound is average.  The mono speaker isn't as crisp or loud as the Lenovo S8, and some users have complained of humming sounds when earphones are plugged in.  This may be due to the placement of the microUSB port, which is right next to the headphone jack. And, ludicrously, is ON THE TOP OF THE TABLET! (see gripe below).

The battery life is average, as expected.  It's comparable to the Lenovo, in that I can get about 3.5 + hours of video playback before draining the battery.  An hour of web browsing will drain the battery 20%, so I figure 4+ if you're just doing that, with brightness down to 40%.  Intriguingly, the back of the tablet snaps off (the entire back) to reveal the microSD slot and the battery - though it's not replaceable.  Though it's tempting, for sure - there are screws back there and I think it would be an easier matter to open this sucker up.  Hmm.

So, for a sub-$100 media consumption device, putting aside issues with Windows 8.1, it's a pretty good deal in my mind.  7 inches is an interesting size these days, as some people at the gym asked me "what phone is that?"  (It's the HP MegaPhone XL!)

Gripes and Missed Opportunities:
1. Putting a charging port on the TOP of the tablet is a major fail.  Granted I can flip the tablet 180 degrees but this puts the Windows home button on the top and it's just weird.  Plus, placing it so close to the audio jack probably has lead to the complaints of buzzing noises (interference).
2. A removable back on a tablet is such a unique thing, and in order to offset it's bulk and heft, having a removable battery there would have been an AMAZING feature.  To my knowledge, there is no tablet currently out there with a replaceable battery.  On a long plane trip, this would add the convenience of swapping out cells when the first one runs down.  It would have been a major differentiator for the Stream.
3. There's a barely noticeable gap between the bezel edge and the top of the screen.  In that gap, there's a little pinhole I assume for a microphone.  However, the gap is definitely a crud magnet and has already started to accumulate some dust.  Another design issue.
4.  I just can't figure out why this tablet has to be so heavy!  The Lenovo S8 uses the same processor (Intel Atom) and has the same battery, but is half the weight.  Maybe I do need to tear it down and see why...

Play-Fi does operate on this, but it drops out much more frequently than it does on my desktop, or my Android tablets (with less RAM). If your needs are small, like a few pages of a MS Word document, or 100 columns in an Excel spreadsheet, or you browse the web, and occasionally watch video, this is a great deal (BTW, a one-year subscription to Office 365 is $75... so it's like you get a Windows tablet for $4 (what's not to like about that?))! It's a great VALUE even for $95, but beware that you may not be able to run your most used Windows apps. UPDATE (3/17/2015): I thought I would write an update to talk about my experience pairing this HP Stream 7 to the iGo Stowaway Ultra-Slim Bluetooth Keyboard for Blackberry and other PDA/ Handhelds, a Bluetooth keyboard, which I purchased on Amazon about seven years ago. So, first off the Stream had Bluetooth turned off. To turn it on, I swiped from the right side and chose [Change PC settings]->[PC and devices]->[Bluetooth]. I switched Bluetooth On, then I tried to pair the iGo Stowaway Keyboard with the Stream. - Nothing -. Well, I was actually picking up phones in the area that I could pair with, but not the keyboard. Then I noticed something that wasn't happening: the light on the iGo Keyboard was NOT flashing. I knew I had new batteries, so I closed the keyboard case, then opened it again, saw the flashing light, pressed [Ctrl]-Blue [Fn]-Green [Fn] together, and -Viola!- I clicked on "Bluetooth keyboard" on the HP Stream (now that it's paired it says "Think Outside Keyboard"), and clicked on [Pair] then typed in a seven or eight digit number on my iGo, and the HP Stream downloaded a driver (or something), and yippee! I was able to use my iGo. Unfortunately, at this time, it appears the "Think Outside" company that produced the iGo Keyboard is either not in business and/or is not updating their drivers for this item. I am not able to use the special [Fn] keys like [Fn]-Numlock and such, but this Stream paired with the iGo make for a great combination for more than the average amount of typing for a tablet. If I ever find an updated driver for the iGo, I will update this review, and maybe this will benefit someone wanting to do the same thing or at least something similar. UPDATE (4/17/2015): Okay, I've complained above about lack of RAM... although I wish it did have more RAM, I have been able to run Quicken on this HP Slate. I tweeked the virtual memory. Microsoft hides virtual memory, so heres a run-down on how I got to it. Click-and-hold the Computer icon in Windows Explorer or This PC from the [Start] menu> Properties> Advanced system settings> Advanced (tab)> [Settings] button>Advanced (tab)> [Change] button. For the C: drive, I unchecked Automatically manage paging file size for all drives and then I selected the option button System managed size, then I click [Set], then [OK], then I rebooted. I haven't had the error messages in Quicken (2015) pop up again, although (sigh) DTS Play-Fi does still drop-out more often than I would like. It's not bad now though. Still 4-stars. I like this Slate, but I don't LOVE it.

When I read the specifications, this seemed like the ideal tablet.  My day job is Windows administration.  Having a device I can use from anywhere when I'm on-call would make supporting my co-workers convenient and easy.  My hobbies include writing and blogging, which also benefit from having Windows and the Internet wherever I am.  So the HP Stream 8 with "real" Windows 8.1, 4G Internet, WiFi, a micro SD slot, a camera, USB, and Bluetooth seemed like my ideal device.

Unfortunately, the tablet I received had a line of dead pixels down the screen. Amazon was great and shipped a replacement immediately.  The replacement had a great screen, but developed bad blocks on the SSD and WiFi trouble in the first night (before I'd installed anything other than Windows and HP updates).  When the tablet would go to sleep, the WiFi card stopped working and had to be switched off and on before it would work again.  Three strike in two tablets.  Both went back to Amazon.

For a $150 tablet, if it hadn't had the hardware issues it did, I'd speak pretty highly of it.  I thought the screen looked crisp and clear (unlike an Acer I once tried to use), the performance was tolerable (for a 1GB RAM Atom based device), touch-screen response was good, and in general it felt solid and comfortable to work with.  It was a little heavier than I'd have liked, but not too heavy to slip into a coat pocket.  I liked the design, except for the micro SD port being under the flimsy plastic cover on the back.  (Though I did like the fact that the cover exposed the battery, which might be replaceable someday.)

I never got to try the 4G internet before I returned it.  If I'd had activation problems, I might have tried swapping the SIM out with the one from my Nexus 7 to see if that worked.

Other things that could be improved here... 1GB RAM is not enough for most mainstream applications.  This device really ought to be 4GB minimum.  With the bundled software and OS, only about 20GB of the 32GB drive could be used.  The device needs either a user-upgradeable SSD or a larger built-in storage device.  You could drop the micro SD if you had that.  Unless the battery was replaceable, I'd want the back cover sealed, with the SIM and SD slots accessible from the side of the device.  A second USB port would also be good, since you have to use the first to charge the device.

I like HP products in general and believe it's a good company, so it pains me to leave a 2-star review, but I have to be honest with my fellow Amazon shoppers.  My experience with the Stream 8 wasn't positive, and I can't in good conscience recommend it based on that.  I'm hopeful that HP will release a second generation of the device that addresses the hardware issues and improves on the specifications.  If so, I'll be one of the first to order it.  My ideal device would be a small, thin, light Windows 8.1 device (think Nexus 7 dimensions) with decent performance, 4G LTE, a good rear camera, and 6+ hour battery life.  Whoever makes that first will get my money.

It also has an SD card slot which is nice, but my 2015 laptop does not have one so initially I had to dig my 2005 netbook out of the closet to transfer data from laptop to netbook then netbook to tablet.  The touch screen is a little "stiff" so you have to be determined to open a function or type a letter, but that is not necessarily always a bad thing because there are less accidental keystrokes (this is without any screen cover or protector). All that being said, overall I am happy with this tablet;  it does the things I wanted to be able to do and it did not cost too much. Before I decided on this tablet I researched for about two months along with the Stream 7 and the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 in 8 inches. What made me choose this over the Stream 7 is the extra inch of screen. I chose this over the Tab 4 mainly because I have had Android in the past (tablets and phones) and besides the HTC Sensation I was not impressed and sometimes downright irritated over how the devices performed. I always hesitate on Android when it comes to any kind of device. I have owned iOS in the past (iPad mini and iPad 4G) and liked the interface but Apple was a bit more costly than needed to be spent at this time.

What Am I Using My Tablet For?

Blogging - I was spending countless hours in front of my work computer updating my blog. My office chair is not that comfy and I felt like I was stuck at work as opposed to posting at leisure.

Email - Due to my working from home I am always getting multiple emails a day and with no tablet that meant that either the email had to come through my phone which kills the battery or through my computer which means that when I'm off the clock I am still stuck to my computer.

Music - I have the XBOX Music Pass because my cell (Nokia 521 Windows 8.1) streams and downloads the music. This was one of my selling points, I didn't want to have to use another music database had I chosen another type tablet since I was already subscribed to the pass.

Social Media - I also use Facebook, Google Plus and LinkedIn. While I can use Facebook on my phone, Google Plus and LinkedIn was a bit more irritating on the cell (Google Plus being the worse).

Productivity - I don't create a lot of documents but I do from time to time and wanted a device that is able to perform certain duties i.e PowerPoint presentations, Word documents and Excel spreadsheets when I need it to.

Entertainment - I watch Netflix, Amazon Prime shows and YouTube a lot. As it stood before I acquired this tablet I had to sit at my computer at times when I just wanted to lounge and relax.

Features

Full Windows 8.1, no RT - The difference between full and RT is that with RT you have a more scaled down version of Windows. You have applications that are compatible but there is a large limit on what you can use the tablet for. I would say it's more in the lines of iOS with the lock down of what you can do. This is fine if you aren't using it for much but I wanted a full experience for the possibilities it created. Full basically means you can do just about everything on it that you could do on your Windows PC. For example, I tested downloading iTunes and was successful in installation, launching and using. This would not have been available to do on RT.

Free year of Office 365 Personal - This would otherwise be $69 to purchase so that's very nice to include.

Free T-Mobile Data - This tablet comes with free data of up to 200mb a month. 200mb is not much but if you're like me and don't really head out much then that's a lot for you. If you require more data there are other prepaid plans you can get or if you have service already this can be added to your cell phone data plan. Only for T-Mobile though; it could work on other carriers but you would have to contact them to find out. Difficulty level in connecting was a 4/5. My SIM card was already in the tablet when it came so in case you see the plastic with the card punched out chances are it's in the tablet.

Battery Life - I have noticed the battery life is draining more than I thought but in all fairness I have been playing with this tablet since I got it. If you are a light to moderate user (check social media, browse the internet and check email) then you should get a day or more out of this tablet. If you're like me and use it for other things like creating documents which requires the screen to be on the entire time then expect the battery to die throughout the day. I have charged this up a couple times and have noticed the battery indicator never reaches 100% charged. It reaches 99% but never that extra percent. Not sure completely why but it doesn't bother me but may bother others. From dead to 99% charged it takes approximately 3-4 hours.

Note: I turned my tablet off and kept it charging all night and when I turned it on this morning it was at 100% charged, indicator green, but didn't stay there but for a couple minutes.

Storage - The storage capacity is 32gb and the amount you can use is 14.7 or something close to that. This decrease in used storage is due to the operating system and pre-installed applications. I did purchase a 32gb micro SD card but I'm wondering if perhaps I need to go ahead and grab the 64gb card instead. The jury is out on that but the SD card by Samsung worked fine and was recognized. To get the SD card to work you just have to do a few file path tweaks to make sure applications, music and files install to the card as well as the C drive.

Device Functionality - Due to the lower specs one would think that the tablet wouldn't perform well, just bare minimum and that's it. That couldn't be more wrong. So far I have been able to use multiple applications at the same time and haven't noticed a decrease in speed or functionality. I think it all comes down to what you are using it for. If you run a lot of powerful applications at once then you may see a dip in overall performance. If you are using Word and listening to music while updating Facebook (like I'm doing right now) them your performance will be fine. Speed also affects hardcore games like World of Warcraft-type heavy graphics. This tablet will not run them and if it does the performance will be abysmal.

Bluetooth - I purchased the Infiland Bluetooth keyboard which came with a case and connected it to the tablet. It took a while to figure out the instructions because what they were telling me to select in the instructions wasn't how it was listed in Windows 8.1. However, I managed to connect it with no extreme issues. Only thing is the Bluetooth installation was a bit slow, took about 5-6 minutes to install. Other than that everything is connected and stable. I also turned the keyboard off and turned it on later and it reconnected without having to set everything back up. Solid experience.

Conclusion

This tablet is meeting my expectations and doing a lot more than what I was looking for. At this price point I wasn't looking all that forward to it because I knew the specs were considered bottom tier when compared to competition in the same price range. I am pleasantly surprised and now can't imagine using any other type tablet. I would highly recommend if your usage is more along the lines of what I use tablets for. If you are a hardcore gamer I would look elsewhere because you will have issues as this isn't a gaming tablet. It's almost a shame to call this a tablet, it's more of a shrunk down computer but when you think of the limitations on graphic heavy games reality comes back that this is a tablet, and a darn good one.

I was thinking about getting the Kindle Fire 6 when it was on sale for $84, when CNET sent me an e-mail about the HP Stream 7 being available for $79. I already have several Kindle Fires, so I thought I'd give the HP a try. It's not a bad little Windows tablet for the price! It runs Windows 8.1 faster than my now 2.5 year old Acer AO-725. I also ordered a Bluetooth keyboard Anker Bluetooth Ultra-Slim Keyboard for iPad Air 2 / Air, iPad mini 3 / mini 2 / mini, iPad 4 / 3 / 2, Galaxy Tabs and Other Mobile Devices (Black) T300 to use on this HP, as well as my Kindle Fires and coupled with an OTG cable and a mouse, turned the HP Stream 7 into a full-fledged, tiny, all-in-one Windows computer. This tablet is very useful for checking e-mail and browsing the web. It also comes with a year's subscription of Office 365 personal edition, which, by itself, retails for $69 at many stores (not Amazon, of course!). I set up Office 365 and played with Word, and it functions just fine on the HP Stream 7. Outlook works great as well! Since this tablet runs the full version of Windows, I downloaded my HP Office Jet 8600 driver to the HP and printed out a couple of Word documents. Worked like a charm! If you need to store a lot of Office-related files, this tablet accepts micro-SD cards up to 64GB, but you must remove the back cover to access it. Not a very hard chore. Given its low price, 1GB of memory and 32 GB of storage and a slower, but decent Intel Atom processor, this tablet is not going to replace a Core I7 laptop or desktop unit anytime soon, but it could come in handy to edit and revise MS Office files on the fly! A very good buy for $79! Now, I'll see how well it holds up before I award it a fifth star!

Once the mouse is detected, the Windows 8 OS displays the classic mouse icon and allows you to navigate the system just like you would a normal PC. On top of that, this specific mouse has a unique little feature to it. There is a small blue Windows touchpad/button to the left side where your thumb sits. If you push the button, it cycles from what ever program you are using to the home screen. If you press it while in the "touchscreen" home screen, it will take you to the normal desktop allowing you to go back and fourth with ease. Plus, if you swipe from the top down, it pulls up your task manager. If you swipe from the bottom up, you can seamlessly switch through the programs that are currently running. It is a truly amazing little mouse. Not to mention it feels great, has good response, and vibrates when you use the touch pad. I am thoroughly happy with the features of this tablet! Speakers: The speakers are loud enough for casual listening but don't have enough power to listen to from too great of a distance. I would say that the speakers are rather weak for my taste. I enjoy listening to music while I work around the house. The good news is that there are many portable Bluetooth speakers that work great. I hooked my tablet up to a JBL Flip Portable Speaker. These speakers are extremely loud and should work well for the majority of people. The Bluetooth works from very far away allowing you to connect to the speaker from almost anywhere in your house. The link to this specific Bluetooth speaker is: JBL Flip 2 Portable Wireless Speaker (Black) Battery Life: The battery lasts me the entire day with moderate use. My use for this tablet starts at 5AM when I wake up to check my e-mail, read articles, etc. I then use it fairly heavily while at my internship. I had an hour long presentation using Power Point on this tablet and continued to use the tablet through the rest of the day even at home. I didn't have to charge it until later at night, around 6 or so. The battery life is pretty good and should last throughout the day. Camera: The camera is not mind blowing by any means. But for a little 2MP camera, it takes decent pictures. If there is any movement, bad lighting, etc. the picture won't come out very well. I am fortunate enough to have a 20MP camera on my Nokia Lumia 930, so I use that instead. As stated previously, I think you will very much enjoy this tablet as long as you take the time to properly research what size fits you best. I will continue to edit this review as I experience more use with this tablet.

When I called T-mobile, they told me it was an invalid SIM # and I had to contact HP.  Contacted HP who told me that T-mobile knows how to activate the tablet, just tel them it's an invalid IMEI issue.  Back to T-mobile:  Two different customer reps insisted I had to set up an account for my "phone."  I gave up with them.  Contacted HP again, HP rep said I did not have to open an account, just get the SIM activated.  Back to T-mobile:  I finally got a T-mobile rep that understood I had a tablet to activate, was familiar with the free data offer and explained I needed to open a pre-paid account that would be loaded with the free data every month, just tell the pre-paid rep that I was activating for the free data.  I get disconnected during the transfer.  UGH!!!!  Call T-mobile AGAIN, go through phone tree hell for the millionth time, get to the pre-paid rep. I give her the SIM #, then she asks for the IMEI number.  She tells me it's not a valid number, so I am not eligible for the free data. I bought this tablet to be my interface into my corporate windows.  It comes with Office Personal - which is 1 full office for the hp stream itself and another install on another PC.  This is a $70/year subscription - first year included on this device makes this an even better value.  I am able to run my corporate VPN software, as well as have my corporate google drive to access my office documents on an approved cloud service.  There is a full version of Outlook - as well as a full version of WebEx and all its integration.  Overall - if you have a Microsoft centric corporation this is a great portable device to be connected into a corporate environment.

The problems
It supposedly comes with 200MB of free data/month (non-rollover) from T-mobile.  If you look online you'll see there are a lot of people posting on HP's website as well as T-mobile saying they can't activate.  I have run into the same issue.  I cannot get the device to activate on T-mobile.

There is just 1 USB port.  You need a USB host cable to use a USB device with it.  It does not come with the host cable.  That same USB port is also the charging port.  The real problem is - the changing is trickle charge.  When you have the device plugged in - you cannot use it and charge at the same time.  Any device usage means the battery is draining - even plugged in.  Definitely not a small desktop replacement with this power issue.

There is no video out.  It supports Miracast - so you'll need some kind of Miracast adapter on your display.  In theory the Amazon Fire Stick will soon support this - and I have one.  That being said - until Amazon updates the fire stick I don't have a way to test Miracast.  This limits its usefulness as a Powerpoint machine.  Miracast or maybe some USB display protocol may work - or in my case have a separate computer connected to the projector and just use WebEx.

It supports 802.11n 2.4GHz band only.  There is no 5GHz support.  It is only $150 - but in this day and age putting out a new device without 5GHz is surprising.  Luckily I have a dual band router at home - but the Cellular Access Point I have only does one frequency - so I have to choose to either run 2.4GHz just to use the Stream8 or stick with the 5GHz for every other one of my devices.  (iOS and Mac devices)

You still need a mouse for desktop apps (Office and Excel are bad with just touch).  There is a software mouse for Windows 8.1 - which works OK - but it is a 3rd party app.

Good product from HP. Solid. A full Windows machine that fits in a suit pocket, with universal internet (subject to cell signal of course). But when you put a 1280x800 display and desktop Windows programs on a 8" tablet, something gives. iPad and Android apps were written for tablets and fingers. Windows menus were designed for a monitor and mouse, so Microsoft has a tougher challenge to migrate that experience to a tablet, and it shows. Most of the time you can't pinch-zoom and put some distance between the options. It works only in browser content and Acrobat documents, not menu bars and forms. So you'll spend a lot of time backtracking from wrongly registered choices. The "screen magnifier" app is flaky and plain useless. When pinch-zoom is available to everything on screen, hopefully in Win10, this tablet will be a beaut. More generally, Win8.1 tablet mode is simply not market-ready, but that's a much longer story. Let's just say it's absolutely critical to have an external keyboard/mouse for sticky situations which will arise often. This adaptor is the key: IVSO Micro USB 2.0 Host OTG Cable for HP Stream 8 and HP Stream 7 Tablet (Black). Screen capture requires a subscription to HP or Microsoft services. You can't save a screenshot to disk. This is unacceptable. Even Android (notorious for routing all data transfers through Google servers so they can Big Brother you) lets you save a screenshot to the SD. The GPS works. Not everything I'd like, but it's there. So if you're looking for a browser on the road, and you run new software designed for tablets, this is great. If you're a power user hoping to slide your legacy laptop DOS/Win programs smoothly to a Win8.1 tablet, expect hiccups. All things considered, this machine is useful, and for the price, it's a steal.

Movies, songs, videos and back-up can all be saved to the SD card. This thing is REAL - Androids seem like toys in comparison. Even the HP Connect music app impressed me. It shows all my album art, displays all the songs and doesn't bombard me with adverts. Much nicer to look at than Windows Media Player. Movies play great. The sound is decent from the external speakers and excellent using earphones. Some complain about a hiss in the earphones but I discovered there is no hiss using Apple iPod ear phones. I have some cheap, generic earphones that I quit using because there was a hiss/buzz especially noticed between songs.

What else? Oh, yes. The battery lasts about six hours with a half-bright screen and the airplane mode turned on which turns off the T-Mobile broadband, the Bluetooth, the wi-fi and the built-in GNSS (GPS navigation receiver). The built-in GNSS works automatically for most apps but for the OpenCPN ocean navigating program it's just not seen by it. This can be corrected by installing and running a utility called Geolocation TCP. Start the utility first and minimize it, then start OpenCPN and it will be able to detect and use the internal GNSS via the utility - but the wi-fi needs to be turned off or the utility will default to using the wi-fi and will be inaccurate.

PC Navigator 14 free, on the other hand, connects to the GNSS automatically without the Geolocation utility so the problem seems to be software and not hardware related.

The USB port is the micro-USB. So, you might need a micro-USB to standard USB cable to connect it to a USB device such as a printer or DVD player.  It has wi-fi and Bluetooth.  Printers using those two wireless protocols should connect without wires. To transfer data and files between my laptop and this tablet, I bought an Imation 32 Gig Two-in-One Micro flash drive. It has both a regular size and micro size male connector built in.  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GROX596/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_1  It works great and is fast.

I also bought a nice little carrying case that fits perfectly,  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00I8T4OLG/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_5

It took me a while to get this fully functional but this is a pretty nice tablet. Its pretty responsive, has a vibrant display, runs full windows, and includes 1-year of Office 365 for 2 devices.

To start, there is something between the glass and the screen. I thought it was dead pixels but it moved after I smacked it against my hand. Occasionally it'll show but I seem to be able to move it out if the way so not worth returning it. Getting the T-Mobile 4G (HSPA/UMTS, not LTE) working took 11 days. I thought it was because T-Mo is weak in my area when I fall out of LTE range but it didn't work in strong T-Mo service areas either. I waited a few days and tried again, this worked for someone on the HP support forums but not me so it was time to pick up the phone. The problem turned out to be T-Mo identifying this device as a cellular phone instead of a tablet so it didn't qualify for free 200 MB/month. After two excessively long calls to HP with some very rude customer service reps, and three lengthy calls with T-Mo and an administrative override, my little Stream 8 has a working WWAN and enough access to cover me on the occasional wifi gaps I come across.

The next problem seems to be administrative. This was advertised as including $25 of Microsoft App Store credit, but there was no code in the box and no email after activation. It took a few calls with HP and Microsoft before they determined it was Amazon's problem, and a few calls with Azn before they just gave up and gave me a $25 partial refund. Since I got this on sale for $150 I guess it worked out, although it was still a waste of time on the phone again. Amazon has since removed all mention of the $25 promotion.

With all the negatives out of the way, I've been using this for a few weeks now mostly for education and work at home access and it is great. I haven't had any issues in the Metro apps, the Windows 7 desktop apps are a little less tablet friendly but all this is probably well known. Performance is decent, I wish it had more RAM so I could use 64-bit Windows and maybe dual-boot Linux but having only 1 GB of RAM hasn't adversely impacted performance so I can deal. Admittedly I don't use any real taxing applications like PS or Illustrator, but it plays movies and low-level games just fine.

Speaking of games, I was able to use my USB Sega Saturn controller and play some MAME with the addition of a USB OTG adapter. I originally bought one of the super cheap ones that pop up on the product page but it didn't work so I bought one from Dell which allowed simultaneous charging and USB peripheral use so that's nice. It also accepted a 64 GB Micro SD card, but you have to shut down and remove the back to access it which is kind of annoying.

The touchscreen seems slightly off sometimes, even after calibration I seem to miss. Not sure if it's too sensitive or not sensitive enough but it can be a bit frustrating. It would also be nice if it had video out like HDMI or something. Supposedly you can hook up to a USB display but I don't have one.  I do have an Amazon Fire TV Stick which supports Miracast but they won't connect (Fire TV shows up as a display but it times out every time), so that's useless. No updates available for either device so I guess it's just not happening.

A few quirks aside, and hopefully it's the exception and not the norm, it's a decent tablet. It's more like a laptop w/o a keboard and trackpad but that's not exactly a bad thing. I'd like to give it 3.5 stars but it's not an option, maybe it'll go up to 4 stars once I put some distance between all that nonsense with custome service.

I picked up an HP Stream 7 tablet on Black Friday for $80 just to see what it could really do, and I have to say, I've been both pleasantly surprised, and equally disappointed by this device.

The build quality is decent but unexceptional, a tad bit on the heavy and chunky side but that's typical for budget devices. Still, compared to sub-$100 Android tablets, this is a nice piece of tech with a decent 720p IPS touchscreen. Battery life seems a bit poor to me, though.

I have a 64 GB micro SD card with 58 GB of MP3s making this a nice portable iPod touch-like device, but having to remove and snap back in the back cover to get at the card slot is just insane.

Performance overall is pretty solid as a tablet, in particular in the Modern UI arena. The 1 GB of RAM prevents you from using it for Chrome, though even in Windows 8 mode, Chrome kind of stinks for touchscreen use.

It can run Minecraft. You need Optifine for Minecraft, plus either an OTG adapter and/or Bluetooth mouse/keyboard, but it will run.

It can run Steam. I played Crypt of the Necrodancer with a Bluetooth keyboard. It was fun. I played Shovel Knight with a Bluetooth keyboard (the NES30) which was also fun. I streamed Metro: Last Light to it using Steam in-home streaming. That actually felt pretty nuts, to be playing that game at 60 FPS on a $99 tablet.

There are some decent Windows 8 apps for reading comics. Personally I prefer a larger screen or at least sharper resolution (like Nexus 7 or iPad Mini Retina if going under 10") for reading comics, but this definitely works in a pinch.

The speakers - er, make that speaker - is pretty bad. Some people complain about headphone buzzing (probably a grounding issue) but I don't have that. Just a bad, tinny, quiet, mono-speaker.

There's a decent $10 case available at Amazon. Buy it if you get this. Also get a bluetooth keyboard and some kind of mouse, and an OTG adapter. They're also available cheaply online.

Honestly this device is 1 GB of RAM and a micro-HDMI out away from being awesome. A $99 tablet with those two additions would be killer.

Also the coating of this thing is like some magical thing that attracts and magnifies fingerprints. It is honestly astounding.

As other IT professionals, I tried a lot of tablets (Android, iOS, and MSFT Surface RT and Pro) and this is the FIRST device which I can really use, as it supports a critical mass of features that I really need:
- Real Windows OS which can run any app I used for dozens of years and can write custom app myself fast in any lanaguage (my need for this feature eliminates Android, iOS and WinRT for me). It beats my previous tablet Nokia Lumia 2520 which had a lot of good features (including free MSFT Office which is not present on HP Stream), but too restrictive WinRT OS
- Real USB keyboard/mouse support, so I can actually do work everywhere without carrying laptop
- Real mobile Internet connectivity (missing this feature KILLS Surface* Pro devices for me - Why there is no simple, unlocked 4G connectivity there???)
- Meaningful battery life up to 8 hours (my Surface Pro dies in couple of hours - ridiculous and any other laptop I have also barely approaches 5 hours - too short for longer flights)
- Fast enough for most tasks but without heating or short battery life
- Small, thin and light enough to use as reader with one hand and large enough to use as PC (I used to have old Sony mini PCs with XP Mobile - but it was too bulky)
- Extensible via SD card, custom SIM and replaceable battery (I have had a few nice slim devices which I thew away started from Compaq iPAQ  ten years ago where battery weaken and the costs of replacement are ridiculous). Easy opening of the back like the phone, to replace SD and battery makes full sense on HP Stream 8.

That said, I think couple of more features (maybe in advanced version) HP Stream 8 would make a really perfect mobile device:
- second micro USB port (frequent switching keyboard and charger is not handy)
- ability to take graphic notes with Wacom digitizer pen (this feature I like on Surface Pro, but again lack of SIM card and mediocre battery life makes it unusable for me)

For all those reviews with battery issues - This is a PC, thus, if you do not close your programs they will continue to run in the background.  Not sleep but actually run.  I have had this for only a day but I have been working with windows 8 and have learned the basics.  So close your programs when done by sliding your finger from the top to the bottom of the screen while the program is open.  It will then be closed.

To see if you have open programs - swipe you finger from the left side of the screen in an inch and back.  You will then see a list of open and running programs.  tab the one you want to open and remember to close them when done.

Sleep mode - does not stop your programs from running.  It basically just turns off your screen and makes you sign back in.  Think your desktop PC.  So when you are done working or playing remember to close your programs, sign out, then turn off.

Apps - If you are an app person and love that convenience, then this is not the tablet for you.  Apps are limited and the ones they do have do not work like the iOS or android ones.  But the internet is the same as your PC and everything there works like your PC.  Unlike my ipad where some sites just don't act right.

Keyboard - the on screen keyboard is a little wacky.  It will hide data input areas,  To get past this - close the keyboard, identify the data to be added, then bring back the keyboard by sliding your finger from the right to see the setting and press the keyboard icon.  Or just buy a wireless keyboard.  Remember you may not always have your keyboard available.

Well enjoy your tablet, I plan too.  You may think that I should put this at a 3 or 4 star because of the limitations I listed.  But since I paid $150 for a tablet PC, I give it back 5 stars.

Oh, and feel free to install you regular programs like itunes, chrome, adobe, office, etc.

This was intended to replace the Nexus 7 I have mounted in my vehicle.  Unfortunately, the tablet lacks a few sensors and therefore doesn't have built-in turn-by-turn directions which makes this a dealbreaker for me.

For some people, this will be an awesome tablet.  It comes with a full version of Windows 8.1, MS Office, and 200 MB of free Tmobile data for life. I'm sure the next version of this tablet running Windows 10 will correct these oversights at which point I'll be making a purchase since this is otherwise a great deal for a solid tablet.

This tablet is a good size to handle with a single hand and the 7" display is very bright and clear.

Being this is a full version of Windows and not the RT version, you can install any software you might install on a desktopnor laptop.

The tablet ships with 1GB RAM which is sufficient to run most applications.  I was also able to run full-screen NetFlix without any issues.

The processor is fast enough for most applications.  I was able to install Google Chrome browser and it ran as well as my desktop version.

However there are some issues.

The amount of RAM installed will limit the tablet to the number applications that can run simultaneously.  Large applications will be laggy as the tablet will have to swap out to the primary storage.

The primary storage is also limited to 32GB, of which approximately 20GB is free after the Recovery partition and the Windows 8.1 installation is done with it.

This means the number of apps that can be installed will also be limited.  I recommend installing a high speed SD memory card and moving the user profile to the memory card so all application data and user files (video, music, data files such as Word and Excel) be saved there instead of the primary storage.

The tablet also comes with a 64bit processor but because the UEFI BIOS is 33bit, Windows is a 32bit installation.  This means that you cannot run 64bit software on the tablet.

The UEFI BIOS also is restricted to UEFI and does not support Legacy BIOS booting.  This and the 32bit limitation means nearly all mainstream Linux distros will NOT install on this tablet without serious hacking.

The last complaint is the functionality of Microsoft Windows 8 in a tablet form.  To be frankly honest, Windows does NOT work well in a touch environment.  While Microsoft exclaims Windows 8.1 is the best tablet-enabled version of Windows; this is a relative statement as there are superior touch-enabled operating systems.

If you want a mobile Windows tablet for running some apps, then this tablet is fine for web browsing, playing media but not suited for anything else.

This is my first attempt at using a windows tablet. Being a student, I was looking for something lighter and easier to bring around. I thought for $150 this tablet might be worth a shot. After playing with it for one day, here is what I think.

-Screen Size: 8" for a windows tablet is probably the bare minimal screen size you should probably go. Sometimes I find it difficult to accurately peck at the window's close, minimize, etc buttons. Overall though, not too bad. With the resolution squeezed into this 8" form factor, it actually looks pretty good.

-Ram: For 1 gb ram, the laptop works acceptably. I changed the virtual memory page size to 2-3 gb, up from the original 1.7 gb default. It seemed to help. I also turned off most of the visual effects except for smoothing edges of screen fonts. I felt this made the tablet feel much more snappy.

-OS: Windows 8. Urgh. Took some time getting used to the metro and charm windows. But once you get the hang of it it is not too bad. I remember first time I played with windows 8 it took me 30 min to figure out how to turn the computer off. Sad day. Google is your friend. There are many hidden windows on the right and left of the screen. It took me a bit to figure out how to enable bluetooth. Apparently you have to enable it by going to the taskbar on the right side of the screen => settings => wireless => view connection setting  => airplane mode. You can see a slider for the bluetooth option there. I have yet to purchase a bluetooth keyboard and will be trying that sometime soon.

-Microsoft Aps: I had an issue here. My IE ap crashed most of the day. Somehow it is now working smoothly...
Also, as another may have mentioned, it is probably better to use internet explorer on this tablet. It does not use as much memory as other explorers such as google chrome. So far I have only tried the youtube ap and it works well.

-Battery Life: From how I was using it, I estimated around 8 hours, more or less the amount HP claimed the tablet should have.

-Sound: The sound from this little guy wasn't too bad with its external speakers. However, there is this ANNOYING static hissing that does not stop while using the earjack. I read online that others had this problem as well. You can avoid this problem by connecting a bluetooth headphone to the device. This drove me less crazy.

-Weight: It is decently light, though not as comfortable in your hand as the samsung's tablets. It is supposed to be 0.9 lbs. I haven't tested this fact myself yet.

-Value. SUPERB. Paying just $150 + tax, you are essentially getting a perfectly functional low-end windows laptop, with 200 mb/ month from t-mobile (you never know when you just might need it), and a year of microsoft office.

In conclusion, as long as you realize this tablet's limitations (don't expect it to run photoshop, games, or other taxing activities), @150$, it is quite the steal.
