This is for the 8" tablet with 4G. I've just had it for a few days, but so far I think it really does what it's supposed to do. Hardware wise, the specs are obviously low end but it has what it needs.

First: the build is solid and unassuming. A bit heavier than the sexier and more expensive tablets, but the plastic build feels solid, durable, and grippy enough  which (combined with the price) means I have no problem using this without a case. With a more expensive tablet I would feel obligated to use a case, so the weight advantage would be negated.

The screen is bright, has excellent viewing angles, and vibrant colors. It suffers from pronounced backlight bleed around the edges, however. This is most noticeable with a black screen, but even with a white screen you will notice it. This is the main reason I knocked off one star. I still think the screen is pretty good for the price, however. If you have used more high end tablets with high resolution screens, you will notice the lack of pixels on this screen particularly with text (using it as an e-reader for example). But it's really a fairly fine distinction, for all intents and purposes the screen is very nice and plenty sharp, perfect for web browsing and video watching. You will probably want to pick up a capacitive stylus because using Windows desktop mode on an 8" screen can be a bit finicky using fingers. But the touch accuracy and sensitivity is as good as you can expect, all told I was pleasantly surprised.

The T-Mobile 4G is a real draw for this tablet. Keep in mind, T-Mobile basically gives away the free 200mb per month to anybody who buys a $10 SIM card. So it's not exactly an exclusive offer. But they do throw in the SIM card with this device, and it's hard to find reasonably priced tablets that have any cellular capability at all, so this is a rare beast. Having the SIM card slot also means you can buy prepaid data SIM's (which I do frequently when I travel internationally) and have internet everywhere you go. A nice feature.

This does have a built in GPS, a rarity among Windows tablets. Keep in mind there are precious few proper turn by turn navigation apps for Windows, the included "Bing Maps" gives directions but not turn by turn navigation.

It does not have any way to export video to a separate monitor or TV, unless you buy a Miracast dongle (I don't have one and don't care, I can export video from my Android phone via MHL if I need that feature on the road).

It does not have a USB port. You can use a microUSB "OTG" adapter instead, but you cannot charge the device and use the USB at the same time. Again, for me, don't really care.

It has a front and rear camera. They work, but are low end. Chances are the camera in your phone is 10 times better.

Performance wise, I place modest demands on the tablet, and it seems to handle everything smoothly. I was worried the 1GB ram would be a problem, but so long as I keep a reasonable limit on the number of tabs and programs I have open it seems OK. This is not the device for video editing or other demanding tasks.

I have a 128GB microSD card in it, no problem there. It plays movies smoothly, and having real Windows 8 means there is no problem with weird formats or codecs. I got about 6.5 hours on the battery watching movies at 50% brightness, which isn't setting any records but you should ask yourself how many hours in a day you want to spend staring at an 8" screen anyway.

A lot has been said about Windows 8 vs. Android vs. iPad. I will try not to rehash the arguments, but simply say if you have an occasional use for legacy Windows programs (which I do) then this is a godsend. Combined with a bluetooth keyboard, It really allows me to ditch the laptop. It's not as good of a "tablet ecosystem" as iPad or Android nor is it as good of a computer as a proper laptop but it does work for all the tablet functions and all the laptop functions I need for a fraction of the cost, weight, and volume. This is coming from someone who spends half his life on the road travelling, but who's work is not particularly computer intensive (Although some proprietary and ancient scheduling software I occasionally need is Windows only). Mostly I just need to email, check facebook, watch movies, read books. Basic tablet stuff. This fits the bill, and thus far it delivers on what it promises.

UPDATE: Some folks have complained about odd background noise using headphones. I can confirm that there is some electrical interference noise. It's not very loud, and not very noticeable when something is playing, but it is there. Might be a deal-breaker for some.

Also, some folks have noticed that the "autohide" taskbar in desktop mode doesn't unhide using touch. I can confirm this as well. The solution is simply not to use auto-hide, or there may be some other workarounds. Some google research reveals that this is a common problem with Windows 8.1 on other tablets as well. Hopefully this will be fixed by a future update since it appears to be a simple software issue.

So for less than iPad mini's price - I have almost 80 GB of free memory to do as I please, whereas in the iPad the available memory to me would have been 12-13 GB. I have already activated the T-mobile 4G connection, and I was quite happy with how fast it was. Enough to get work done. So, for me, I love the value this tablet is offering. But I rated it 4 star (probably would have given 3.5 if it was possible) because of its limitations.

Pros of the device (HP Stream 8) - See images uploaded:
1) Storage - comes with 32 GB (around 18 GB available to you) + expandable - I put a 64 GB (58.5 available) SDXC card
2) Price - $ 179 for 4G enabled tablet
3) Screen is IPS - most cheaper android tablets are not. 1280 x 800 isn't the highest resolution but gets your work done.
4) Decent build quality - should last
5) USB "On the go" capability - with a $ 8- $ 10 OTG cable, you can convert the micro USB port into a full size USB to attach keyboard or mouse, or a powered hub to attach other devices.

Pros of the Operating System (you will get these pros on this device, but also on other tablets running win 8.1)
1) Runs Win 8.1 - this is a mini computer, with a complete desktop mode, my computer, control panel and like - what that means for you is that say you want to install any non power intensive traditional windows program (e.g., VLC player) or want the familiarity which you have with your work or home computer, you can switch to desktop mode and enjoy it. This is not Win 8.1 RT - which you should run away from!
2) Quality free apps - remember Microsoft is no Blackberry/RIM (I also bought a playbook by those people and they stopped supporting it just one year down the line). Microsoft creates quality software, and in their app store, they have provided plenty of free quality apps. The home screen layout is beautiful with live tiles refreshing itself.

Cons of the device (HP Stream 8):
1) Plasticity feel due to back cover - no where as premium as an iPad, or a galaxy note's synthetic back
2) SD card is below removable cover, which you need to remove extra carefully - so clearly you can't keep swapping cards
3) No mini HDMI out
4) Just 1 GB ram - it doesn't impact the win 8.1 apps from store, but if you run intensive programs in desktop mode, they will run slow or not at all
5) Just one micro USB port which you need to use for charging as well as OTG (connecting keyboard, mouse etc.) So you can either charge the device or use a keyboard/mouse.
6) Sleep mode isn't sleep mode. 80% charge, put it to sleep - next morning its dead. That does not happen with my win 8.1 computer, iPad or even blackberry playbook. Also, unlike an android tablet or iPad's sleep mode, where some apps keep refreshing and give you notifications when needed, when this tablet will sleep, it will really sleep (as good as shutdown)
7) The screen is a finger print magnet - more than any iPad - it does not have oleo-phobic coating
8) Screen's glass has a sticky feel to it. Its weird but I have never felt that way with other tablets/screens.
9) Battery life is only 4 hours with a good brightness (which you enjoy) and 5 hours max with dim lighting (you'll hate it!)

Cons of the Operating System (you will get these cons on this device, but also on other tablets running win 8.1)
1) Very very very few apps - no subway surfer, just one angry birds (that too paid), and almost no google ecosystem apps. If you are buying the tablet mainly for apps (e.g., online banking etc) then you will be very disappointed.
2) The desktop mode is a great plus, but to be honest it is tough to use with a touchscreen - press and hold for options and then use your pinky finger and hope you clicked the right option.

Other thoughts:
1) Invest in a Bluetooth keyboard like Logitech K810 and bluetooth mouse like Logitech T630 - these devices can support multiple tablets/computers and then you can really enjoy this tablet for the hybrid it is.
2) There was a problem with my order but Amazon was wonderful. Assuming amazon's price is competitive (I would say even if it is a little bit more) but it from them because the peace of mind is worth it!

I recently purchased the HP Stream 7 from Amazon. At the time I purchased, it was $99, but I notice that the price has gone up by a little over twenty bucks since then. I'm going to describe my experience with the Stream 7 in comparison to the various other tablet devices I am familiar with. I currently use a Kindle Fire HD 8.9 on a daily basis, as well as an iPad 2 which I use mostly for email and media streaming. In addition, I own a Nexus 7 (2013) that was in daily use until I sat on it and cracked the screen. My comparison is mainly based on my Nexus 7 experience, as the screen sizes are more similar than the other devices.

When I was shopping for a Nexus 7 replacement I ran across the Stream 7 for $99. I was impressed by the fact that I could get a tablet with the complete Windows 8.1 OS for such a low price and decided it would be worth taking a shot at it, especially since it comes with a year's worth of Office 365. The Office 365 license includes a license for another computer in addition to the Stream 7, so it was basically as though I was paying an extra $30 over the Office 365 subscription price to get the tablet. This math doesn't really apply if you don't plan to use the Office suite of software, of course. This is a sensational $30 device but is a more dubious value for $99, much less the current $123 price.

First, the good stuff. This is a full Windows 8.1 computer that fits in your pocket. That is pretty cool, indeed. You can load apps from the default app store as well as downloading and installing software as you would with any Windows computer. I was able to load a variety of free apps including photo editing software, games, the Office 2013 software (as part of the Office 365 subscription), and other software from a variety of websites. Everything I tried to install ran, although I did have some problems with the Windows 8.1 user interface that are not related to the device itself, other than the fact that Microsoft seems to have some problems with understanding how people are going to try to interact with the 7" screen (more on that later in this review).

Upon initial setup you are prompted to supply your Microsoft user credentials so that everything will synchronize with your other devices in the cloud. Frankly, I don't think that Microsoft does as seamless a job of this as Google, but that is my personal opinion. You do have the option of using a local account if you want to forego the cloud features. Once you've supplied the required information, the computer will finish the setup automatically. This took about 10-15 minutes on my home network. If you are already familiar with Windows 8.1 you shouldn't have much trouble getting used to the user experience. In my case, I had to spend a while getting used to the differences between Windows 7 and Windows 8.1. Once I figured out the various gestures to navigate among screens it wasn't too hard to get going. That's where I started to run into some things that I found really frustrating.

The screen resolution on the Stream 7 is 1280 x 800, as opposed to 1920 x 1200 for the Nexus 7. That is a pretty big difference when you are trying to read text or trying to view a busy web page. Although you can zoom in and out with gestures, the Stream didn't seem to respond as well to pinching in and out as the Nexus 7. The screen is OK for looking at pictures, but still not as good as the higher resolution Nexus 7. To add to the general frustration with the screen resolution, the graphics drivers from Microsoft don't seem to work very well at rendering web pages that require scrolling back and forth. Ironically, this includes the Stream 7 page at the Hp website. I had to turn the tablet sideways to read a lot of pages that work just fine on my other devices in portrait mode, which was pretty annoying. I'm not sure whether this is a Microsoft problem or an HP problem, to be fair.

Battery life is another area where this device seemed to suffer. If I turned the device on and then left it alone for a while, the battery would go dead pretty quickly (someplace between 3 and 5 hours, I would guess). If I used it to do stuff like check email and browse the Internet it would die even more quickly. I did some research and found that this is partially caused by a feature called Connected Standby that allows the tablet to receive notifications from Skype, Facebook, and other applications when it is turned off due to inactivity. Microsoft doesn't provide a way to turn the feature off, but I was able to find a way to edit the registry to deactivate it. That dramatically improved the battery life, but it also made it take much longer for the device to wake up after standby. With Connected Standby enabled, the device will wake up almost instantly. With the feature disabled it takes something more in the order of 30 seconds. I'd prefer that there be a simple way to turn it on and off. By way of comparison, the Nexus 7 and the other devices all handle standby mode better, have power settings that are easier to configure, and have better battery life.

I didn't try using an external keyboard with the Stream 7. The on-screen keyboard is OK, I guess, but I really missed the Swype-style keyboard on the Nexus 7. I'm not sure why this isn't baked into the device, but it really should be. This is a matter of personal preference, but it is something I have mentioned to everyone that I've talked to about the device.

The other thing that is worthy of mention is that the side of the case is oddly shaped. The back is slightly wider than the front, which makes it easy to grasp when you are holding it. The problem is, it also makes it awkward to pick it up when it's sitting on a flat surface. This might be less noticeable with a case.

To summarize, I really want to be able to say that this tablet is a great value. I'm impressed that Windows can fit on it and be usable. I like the fact that it comes with a year's worth of Office. However, I'm disappointed with the way text is rendered by Windows and with the Windows 8.1 interface, in general. I intend to upgrade it to Windows 10 as soon as I can, in hope that some of my frustrations will be resolved by the developers at Microsoft. Until Windows works better on the Stream 7, I can't really give the device more than a 3-star review for MY needs. For $99 it might be worth playing with, but if the price is any higher than $99 you'd probably be best served with a good Android tablet or an iPad mini (if you can find one on sale).

SO I have had this tablet for 3 days now.  Understandably, three days is not nearly enough time to test all of the aspects of the tablet but it is more than enough time to get an idea of what to expect.  With that in mind, here goes:

CONS

1. Not enough hard drive capacity: I reinitialized the tablet three times to see if I could get the hard drive capacity to increase but it is pretty steady that you will only get between 19-20 GB out of the 32 GB at start up.  I can't find a reason for the differing amount (mines ranged from 19.6 to 20.3) but I guess that is dependent on what programs are activated at start up.  Also, it appears that the drive amount steadily decreases (with me adding nothing new) to about 14-16 GB as the tablets stays on.  I have searched the drive and can't find any particular reason for this as the drive consistently only shows a total of 12-14 GB  being used on the C drive.  I have not been able to locate where the other 5-7 GB is going.  Safe bets would be to only count on 10-15 being available eventually as I am chalking the discrepancy up to app storage and updates that, for some reason, are not showing up on the C drive.

2. Screen bleed: Light leaks around the edges of this screen like crazy.  I would imagine that this is one of the areas where HP had to cut corners in order to keep the tablet in the targeted price range.  It's by no means a deal breaker (as many tablets and back-lit TV's have screen bleed) but something to consider if you're planning on watching a lot of video in the dark or reading a lot in in dark or low light areas.

3. Charging: The charger for this tablet is TERRIBLE.  I routinely leave it plugged in for an hour and it gets only about 10-15 percent more charged.  it takes well over 5 hours to get a full charge if the tablet is below 10%.  I would say this is a cost cutting measure too but chargers are relatively cheap so this is more of a laziness issue or something that HP just simply didn't put a lot of effort into.  I imagine some of it has to do with the fact that this is a full fledged Windows OS device  that is trying to charge off of a micro USP port.  Windows is far more of an energy hog than Android.

4. Touch screen sensitivity: The touch screen can be finicky at times and, in my observation, only really occurs either in the desktop mode or with the IE Explorer on the tablet side.  Not completely sure why that would be the case when it works fine everywhere else but I know at least part of it is related to the fact that the screen only supports 5-touch multi-point instead of the more widely used 10-touch multi-point.  That said, this isn't a deal breaker either as the screen, overall, works just fine. Just be aware that in some screens (particularly the aforementioned ones) you will need to be more precise than you normally would have to be.

On-Screen Keyboard: In desktop mode, be aware that the on-screen keyboard does not pop up automatically when you press in an editable field like the navigation or address bar or even a document. You have to manually select it from the task bar tray and there appears t be no way to make it automatic from the desktop.  In tile mode and everywhere else it works just fine.

App store: There are a LOT of apps missing from the Microsoft app store that are commonplace in the Apple App store and Google App store (like Groupon).  Additionally, some of the ones that are there are not free as they are in the other app stores (like XFinity Live).  That said, since this is basically a handheld computer, you can access the actual websites of any of the apps as you would on a laptop or desktop.  Where this will hurt you mostly is games as popular and well known games such as Temple Run and Candy Crush simply don't exist on Microsoft's App store.  Don't get me wrong though, there are a lot of games (good games actually) on their app store... just not ones you're used to seeing.

Now, with that out of the way, here is what everybody came to read... the Pros!

PROS

Full Fledged Windows 8.1:  This is not a watered down version or even modified (like Windows RT) but is, in fact, the complete Windows 8.1 operating system.  I have delved into the innermost parts of the program and found nothing lacking.  It is all there.  Even a partitioned amount for a recovery which also may help to explain the missing GB from my earlier comments. In theory, whatever you can do on a laptop or desktop should be feasible on this tablet with reasonable limitations of course.  Interestingly, those limitations won't likely come as a result of the processor or 1GB RAM.  Speaking of which...

Intel Atom Z3735G Processor/Performance: This is one of the newest chips that Intel has put out (came out in May 2014) and while not expensive, it does carry the Intel torch like a champ and does nothing to tarnish the "Intel Inside" legacy.  The chip provides a snappy response no matter what you are doing and I have not experienced any lags of any sort save but one (more on that in a minute).  Keep in mind that I am TRYING to cause problems with the tablet up front.  It's what I do because I will return a device (especially tablets, Laptops, and desktops) if they can't do what i need them to do.  To that end, I have opened a maximum of 6 web pages and had 3 other apps going without a problem which I believe is more than what most people will do.  Go more than that and the chip struggles and will, in fact, give you the dreaded "page/system/program not responding) box that is common to PC's.  In short, keep it moderate and you should be alright. This is not a power user's device.  And in regards to the one issue with lag, it is in the screen rotation.  There is an obvious and prolonged delay in changing the rotation (1-2 seconds).  Given the responsiveness elsewhere, I have no choice but to assume that this is a Windows 8.1 issue and not a hardware issue as the chip powers through just about everything else. If it is really annoying to you though, you do have the option of locking the screen into one orientation.  Mine is locked into landscape mode. In any case, I have owned several "Intel Atom" devices and, in my experience, performance has never been an issue with them.  It looks like the HP Stream 8 is more of the same.

Screen:  Yes the screen makes it onto the Pros side of things too and rightfully so.  It is sharp, bright, and responsive (given the previous issue I discussed).  It is noticeably HD contrary to what others have stated.  I have downloaded a number of HD pictures and videos and they have looked and played just fine.  While it is a fingerprint, smudge, and dirt magnet, I don't know many tablets that aren't so it doesn't get a strike on that.  The only other minor issue is the lack of auto brightness as a feature.  Again though, when you consider what you have (a laptop in PC form) it is acceptable as it is no different form it's PC counterparts so again, no strike is given.

Software: Full Microsoft Windows 8.1? Check. Office 360 free for a year? Check. Connected HP cloud backup services? Check. Free Dropbox storage? Check.  Free monthly Skype allotment? Check. The ability to download and run ANY other software that your Windows laptop or desktop can run? Double check! In fact, this last one is pretty much the one thing that this tablet can do that no other tablet in it's class or price range (Android, Windows, or otherwise) can do which makes it an attractive device.  There are other 8 inch WinMo 8.1 tablets (like the Dell Pro and Toshiba Encore) but they go for $80 to $100 more than this one.  And Given that I got this on sale at $139 (down from its normal price of $179), that made it even more of a value.  Throw in the fact that there is no bloatware to be found (unless you consider the HP Connected app and Dropbox bloatware), the tablet comes ready to get to get down to business and optimized right out of the box.

Build Quality: It is heavy.  Not overbearingly so but it is heavier than similarly sized tablets.  In fact, in hand, it weighs only slightly less than my 10 inch android Asus TF300T Transformer tablet. Other than weight though, the dimensions make it a quite palatable device for holding with one hand  though, admittedly, small hands might still have a problem with doing so.  And while the entire construct is plastic, it is solidly built with no gaps edges or wayward crevices to be found. The battery cover seals tightly and as evidence of its tightness, it requires mild effort to take off or snap back on. Not difficult mind you but definitely requiring more effort than what I was used to having used plastic phones like those in the Galaxy line. The screen is so tight in fact that it looks like I could pour water on it and it wouldn't seep through.  This is where the heritage and benefits of buying tablets from an actual PC maker really show.  This also makes the screen bleed issue even more befuddling since it is obvious that HP put a lot of effort into the construction of this tablet.  Aside from that, there is a minimalist approach to the tablet with it having only two physical bottoms (volume and power and one capacitive one.  A single micro USB port and headphone jack is the only other thing you will find on the tablet.  The sim card and SD card storage are behind the back cover which, actually, is refreshing for me. I don't know how many times I lost SD cards because I (or my kids) have inadvertently ejected them either because they had no cover or the cover was flimsy.  That said, HP is banking on the fact that you will not be removing that SD card because of the low storage amount provided with the tablet. I have a supplemental 16GB card in mine and I don't plan on taking it out or using it up anytime soon.

Features: Screen projection works.  You need only connect to a wireless TV or to a an adapter connected to a regular TV and, voila... your screen will be projected.  I used the Belkin
Belkin Miracast Video Adapter that is sold on Amazon for $59.99. As a side note, that adapter works with just about any Miracast enabled device including my Asus tablet and LG G3 smartphone.  Moving on, I am thoroughly impressed with the Outlook app.  if you are familiar with the new GMail app that allows you to add any email account, it is similar to that but way more refined with a better layout and intuitive usability.  I have four email accounts setup (the one mandatory Outlook one of course) and it does a stellar job of sorting, providing notifications, and previewing those emails.  In fact, just about every standard app has a gorgeous design and layout.  I suppose I have looked at stretched out tablet sized phone apps on android tablets for so long that I'd grown used to blank spaces and unusable space.  Not so with Microsoft.  these app were designed for PC and Tablet consumption and it shows.  So much so that I have stuck to the native weather, news, and photo apps of Microsoft.  And this was after downloading my usual ones from the Microsoft App store (Weatherbug, Flipboard, VLC Player).  Even my beloved Flipboard didn't look as good as the native news app (though Flipboard looks very good on this tablet).  To that end, all of the usual suspects are available on this tablet that would be available on your PC (Media Player, Paint, Office, IE Explorer) and just like how you wouldn't sub out many of those programs and services on your PC, you won't be inclined to do so on this tablet either.  On a side note the IE explorer app (different from the desktop IE Explorer that is on the tablet) is very good and very fast.

4G: This is THE aspect that pushed this tablet over the edge and among the primary reasons I am taking the jump from android tablets to Windows tablet.  There are not many tablets in general with 4G connectivity that are inexpensive and even fewer than run full Windows and/or were compatible with TMobile's network.  I was looking at the Galaxy Tab 4 8.0 with 4G (which retails currently for $299) and, after that, I had to make the jump to a 10 inch tablet which I was trying to avoid for portability reasons.  I consider 7 inch tablets to be too small especially considering that my G# smartphone has a 5.5 inch screen. I was all ready to buy the Tab when this tablet came out and, given the price, it was exactly where I thought it should be spec-wise with two exceptions: 4G and full Windows 8.1.  Unheard of.  At $179, I was willing to take a chance and when the price dropped to $139 for their lighting sale, there was no way I could pass up the chance to see if it worked.  To that end, the tablet comes with 200MB of 4G data for life for free.  Nice to know and I will keep that in mind but I pooped in my TMobile data which comes with 5GB monthly and it has worked just fine.  Given that I have it set to connect primarily with WiFi even when the 4G data is on, I don't anticipate that I will ever get to the 5GB limit unless WiFi catastrophically fails everywhere.  In any case, the 4G has often been the faster connection no matter what WiFi I have been on but I am in a big city (Houston) so I have very good and expansive 4G coverage.  This may not be true for everyone.

Summary

All in all, I would say that this tablet is as good a value as it comes especially if you were able to pick one up during the lightning sale when it was $139.  So far it has performed well but I intend to update this review later after more substantial time has passed.  I would also caution against those that use tablets for gaming or extreme media consumption as this tablet is not designed with that in mind.  Think of it as a more portable and usable netbook which was the small laptops that died an untimely death BECAUSE of tablets.  And just like those netbooks were designed more for reading, document editing, and an overall portable PC device for students and business people, this tablet is designed for the same people.  That said, it can definitely handle media consumption as evidenced by the fact that I bookmarked the actual Hulu site and watched movies and episodes from there without problems.  Music, of course, is no problem with Windows Media Player onboard as well as HP's music app (which can be uninstalled).  The bottom line though is this: understand the device you have.  it is a PC first and a tablet second.  Where it has potential to shine is in document creation/editing, web browsing, reading, and music because these are the menial tasks that your PC usually handles.  This tablet is built to takeover those low level PC activities that you really don't want to start up your laptop or PC for while being ultra portable.  That's it.  If you want high media consumption, gaming, or are stuck on the app-centric android platform, then find yourself an android or Apple tablet that satisfies those needs.  But if, like me, you don't like firing up your laptop JUST to open/edit/create a document, listen to music, get a little real work done (on a platform just as stable as your laptop) but don't need the bells and whistles of an android tablet, this is your tablet.  I don't know that I would ever spend the requisite minimum $500 for a Surface tablet but I think that if this tablet is a success, you will likely see better spec'd full Windows tablets in the near future to start stealing away the average android and apple tablet users that do schoolwork or business.  While I have no problem creating and editing doc on Docs to Go on my android Asus tablet, as a business professional, it is quite refreshing to open up a spreadsheet and find the same options and editing tools that I have on my PC (though, admittedly, I have not used it for work yet).  That familiarity to the average student and non-executive business worker (they can afford the Surface Pro) can mean a lot and with this tablet, HP is vying to find out just how much.  If that niche is there like I think it is, HP and Windows may have just hit a gold mine especially if the moderately spec'd tablet can perform reasonably and ably.

Surprisingly mediocre effort by HP, when I first took it out of the box I was enamored with this $99 marvel.  I agree with other peoples first impressions with the device.  Runs full windows? Awesome! Small and light? Great! The screen? The screen is gorgeous.  I knew there would be some sacrifices like it having a significantly shorter battery life than most tablets, I was ok with that. However, two weeks in, now that the honey moon is over. I've really started to feel where HP cut corners to deliver the product. If you check the HP forums, there are tons of people with issues.

My first issue is the charging situation, this bugger is picky as to which charger lets it charge to 100%, every charger you plug in works for a little bit then it stops. Unless you use the official HP charger & cable... which as of this writing they don't sell in the US store, so if you need a spare you're SOL. To add insult to injury, HP in their wisdom has elected to not put in a charge indicator on the device, so to check the charge you have to turn the device on, navigate to your desktop and check the taskbar icon because the battery indicator in the windows modern UI doesn't give you percentages.

Next Wifi keeps dropping and that's related to the current software drivers (hopefully), I've resorted to using a USB wifi dongle attached via the OTG port when I need to do things where I won't get disconnected. I think for most people, they'll think the wifi drops are just slow internet, but when you're VPN'ed into work and the bugger disconnects your VPN every few minutes, it's hecka noticeable (and I have tried it from many different Wifi networks where my (full sized) laptop has had no issues).

Third there is that as I like to call it, "touch sensor, audible biofeedback," the headphone buzzing other people mention? It gets louder and softer, depending on if you're touching the screen or dragging your finger across it. HP actually told me that I shouldn't experience this issue if I were to switch to bluetooth headphones, which is true but is beside the point.

Remember how I said I didn't mind the short battery life? Well, yes but, here's the thing you have to remember, this isn't a true tablet like an ipad or nexus, it is a computer without a keyboard. What does that mean? Unlike other device, when you hit the power button those devices actually stop using battery however, the stream 7 is different. Even when you think your device is sleeping, it could be awake running something in the background killing your battery. I've had more than once, put the device to sleep, gone to run a task and come back to a super hot & drained device, because some app didn't let the system go all the way to sleep. Once it was windows media sharing that did that, heck that's a MS program! Normal issue of a laptop/desktop, kinda of something that throws you when you're dealing with a tablet.

Now negatives aside, here is what I do like, I like the USB OTG so far as long as it isn't a high powered device like a hard drive, I've been able to plug it in and use it. From a wired ethernet adapter, 4G LTE modem, USB memory card readers, and USB biometric readers; as well as the aforementioned USB wifi dongle. As i've said the screen is gorgeous and is bright, I have no problems using it outdoors at my local starbucks and it gets dim enough that I can read a kindle book in bed. I love being able to run my normal windows applications, real office, real chrome, real VPN with real putty, on a tiny little device. I like a few of the media consumption apps like Hulu, Plex and netflix, which just work better in windows modern/metro mode than they do on the desktop (mostly).

I'm still not sure this is a keeper, it feels like there are one too many sacrifices you have to accept to make it work. Granted it is early days for a lot of the components in this device, that with time & new drivers issues like the wifi drops will disappear. What I mean is, that the wifi component for example, was only released by the chip maker to manufacturers in Sept and drivers were in beta/pre-release until mid October.  If you aren't an early adopter, not a self troubleshooter, it might be best to leave this until version 2 comes out or at least until the drivers mature in 7 or 8 months.

I've always wanted a full Windows 8 powered tablet since the Surface tablets appeared, but since they're substantially expensive and the full Windows ones don't come with 4g connectivity I never bought one. This season HP came out with their string of Stream laptops and tablets it caught my attention. Obviously if money is a big constraint then stop reading now and buy Stream 7 for $99. Personally I've always found the 7" a bit too small for my taste and with the added 1" screen real estate, 4g and 200MB of lifetime data the $79 extra goes a long way. I also picked up a Samsung Evo 64GB micro SD card for $25 last week.

Compare that to a 64/128 GB iPad mini with 4g connectivity and you immediately see how much more value for money this tablet is! To be fair you have to compare it to the older mini models, which you can buy from Apple refurb outlet for around $400, but still the HP is less than half the price. And the OS isn't merely an app launcher, its a full powered desktop OS with Office for a year and where you can pretty much run any consumer software without a lot of problems. I'm not a gamer so can't comment to that aspect, but I've used Excel and it works without much problems and I've Chrome opened now with 2 video tabs, 4 other tabs and this window where I'm writing the Amazon review on full website. All this with the customized Chrome signed in with all extensions and add-ons enabled. No stutter at all.

Of course there are compromises and some problems, like the camera quality is poor (I don't use tablets for taking photos, but only for video chat), tablet gets hot when watching flash videos for an extended time, display barely qualifies as HD, RAM could've been 2GB, audio output jack produces some static/hissing noise, touch isn't 100% intuitive always etc. etc. However it satisfies my biggest needs, full Windows powered tablet, micro SD slot, micro SIM slot with 4g (no LTE) and under $200. I'm traveling now and is in Asia and didn't bring a laptop this time and will update the review as I spend more time. The battery has lasted for 5 hours, with 2 hours of video and the rest Excel and Chrome, and shows 40% remaining. So should get the 8 hours or so the HP specs claims. I recommend this tablet to anyone as a very viable (and most cases better) budget option to iOS and Android tablets.

Typed on an HP Stream 8!

-- Update Jan 2015 --

Now that I've owned the tablet for more than a month I can add a few more things.
1) The tablet is unlocked and can be used with any SIM card (GSM 3g/4g), this came in very handy while I was in Asia.
2) The battery life is not great and lasts 4-6 hours depending on your use. The sleep function isn't exactly power saving and drains battery. I found closing all the apps/programs helps to some extend in this regard. Pull up all the apps that are open and drag them from the top bar all the way down to close it, alternatively you can also use the task manager and processes tab on it.
3) Internet Explorer (with an ad-blocker) works better than Chrome, in terms of using less computing resources and power, even though I prefer Chrome because of the extensions/add-ons I have enabled on it.
4) Most HD videos play flawlessly, upto 720p (I use VLC metro app) and the tablet can get hot/laggy if you want to play 1080p full HD via Chrome.
5) Update your drivers from the HP website and remove unwanted bloatware (to be honest there is very less bloatware on this machine).
6) Amazon refunded me $30 when they slashed the price to $149, now it has gone back up to $179.

All said, for $150 bucks you'd be hard pressed to find another tablet with similar specs. Still 5-star despite the negatives.

For the price, this is the best tablet out there.  Yeah, there are higher-powered tablets, and there are cheaper tablets, but this one hits the sweet spot. WITH the free 4G for life and Office 365, it's a steal.  Note: You can eat through the 200 MB/month *FAST*, though.  I've only been using the 4G for a few hours, and have already used 1/4 of my monthly allotment.  I highly recommend using Windows 8.1's desktop Task Manager's "App history" tab to find what apps use the most data, and restrict them if you can.  200 MB is not enough for 'day to day use,' it is truly 'emergency use only' amount.  But if you need it, it will be a lifesaver.

The tablet itself is of good build quality, with good quality (although fingerprint-prone) plastic back that pops off easily to get to the micro SD slot and SIM slot.  The screen is VERY high quality, and with my not-perfect vision, just as easy on the eyes as an Apple "Retina" display.  If you have 20/20 or better, it should be just on the edge of "can't see the pixels" quality.  The cameras are of "good enough for video chat" quality, not going to replace even a mediocre dedicated camera, and video quality is likewise limited.  But usable for the primary purpose of video chat just fine.  Skype works in dim lighting just fine.

The CPU and GPU are fast enough for everything I've thrown at it, including some very complex Excel spreadsheets and some light gaming (Minecraft was playable, although I did have to reduce a few of the visual settings.)  The storage was sufficient for the OS, Office, a few games, and a couple HD feature-length movie downloads.  I chose to use the SD slot for extra storage just for media, rather than fill up the internal SSD.

So far, I only have three minor complaints:
1. While it supports USB On-the-go (you can plug USB devices in through an adapter, so you can connect a full keyboard, mouse, USB flash drive, or any USB device supported by Windows,) that usage shares the port with charger - and unlike some Samsung devices, the Stream 8 doesn't support USB OTG and charging at the same time.  (I have a Samsung adapter that allows both at the same time, the charging function doesn't work when I have a USB device plugged in, too.)
2. No video out: Micro HDMI would have been nice to add.  Yes, it does support Miracast, but the Microsoft Wireless Display Adapter is $60.
3. You have to remove the back to get to the microSD slot and SIM slot.  While for the SIM that isn't a big deal (although I do swap between two SIMs somewhat often,) it is annoying for the microSD.  It relegates the microSD slot to "extra storage only" status, rather than an easy-to-use slot for transferring files.

Heavy for its size and both cameras have low resolutions which is apparent when you see what results are.  Great Windows 8.1 (full version) tablet for the price.  If you are an Amazon Price member, $79 with shipping included.  How low can you go?

This is a wonderful little tablet - cheap, light, with a ton of functionality, sturdy and well built. It comes from full Office for a year ($70 on its own), and it runs it well, as long as you don't load monster Word or Excel documents.

The killer feature, though, is the free 4G cellular data - those 200 MB a month can last for quite awhile if you use it for occasional e-mail, and T-Mobile has very reasonable prices if you want to add more. This makes the Stream 8 a very decent mobile office when on the road, and incredibly versatile when paired with a cheap bluetooth keyboard.

Only weak point: the screen resolution is a bit low (although better than tablets this size) and the viewing angles are not stellar.

For any other thing, though, it is an excellent tablet that is way better than the price may suggest. Windows 8.1 is very snappy on this hardware. Totally worth buying.

The Stream 7 is a great value and its Intel architecture allows running common Linux distributions.

I installed Ubuntu Mate 14.10 32-bit on the Stream 7 and it is running well. Some things are not yet working such as the built-in Wifi (I am using a USB Wifi adaptor) and the touchscreen, (I am using an external mouse and a on-screen keyboard). I will attempt to install drivers and update the review. It seems pretty usable in its current state.  As you probably know, an OTG adaptor and USB hub are required to do this. Press the power button and then volume down to enter the UEFI Startup Menu, the Secure Boot option needs to be disabled.

The Stream 7 has a 32-bit UEFI but most Linux distros only support 64-bit UEFI's so the below tweaks are required to create a live USB drive to boot from. It involves getting an install image called Fedlet that already has a 32-bit EFI directory and copying it to an Ubuntu USB and tweaking the grub.cfg file:

Download the latest Fedlet ISO file from [...] and burn it to a USB drive, (or just extract the EFI directory).
Download the Ubuntu ISO file and burn it to a USB drive (I used a 32-bit image but 64-bit images can boot with this method as well although the file layout is slightly different, the 32-bit method is described below):

 - Copy the Fedlet EFI directory to the root of the Ubuntu USB drive.
 - Rename the Ubuntu USB /EFI/BOOT/grub.cfg file "grub.cfg_FEDLET" (or just delete it).
 - Copy the Ubuntu USB /boot/grub/loopback.cfg file to /EFI/BOOT, and rename it "grub.cfg".
 - Edit the new /EFI/BOOT/grub.cfg file like below, changing each "linux" and "initrd" label to "linuxefi" and "initrdefi":

Change this:

 menuentry "Try Ubuntu MATE without installing" {
  linux /casper/vmlinuz  file=/cdrom/preseed/ubuntu-mate.seed boot=casper iso-scan/filename=${iso_path} quiet splash --
  initrd /casper/initrd.lz

To this:

 menuentry "Try Ubuntu MATE without installing" {
  linuxefi /casper/vmlinuz  file=/cdrom/preseed/ubuntu-mate.seed boot=casper iso-scan/filename=${iso_path} quiet splash --
  initrdefi /casper/initrd.lz

The Ubuntu USB should now boot on the Stream 7.  As you probably know, you can boot the live USB and try it out without installing it. I was able to install Ubuntu to the Stream 7's disk (eMMC drive) with no additional tweaking, it seemed to install both 64-bit and 32-bit EFI's allowing me to toggle the 32-bit EFI to boot successfully.  I wiped the entire disk clean first using Ubuntu's GParted.  I first made recovery media in Windows using the Recovery Manager utility and a 8 GB USB drive in case I want to restore the tablet back to factory configuration. I am also planning a dual boot install with Windows.

You can also run the Fedlet image, the touchscreen works but it ran slowly and seemed unstable on the Stream 7 so I went with Ubuntu which seems stable, runs as fast as Windows 8.1 and uses less memory.

Hope this helps.

UPDATE January 7, 2015:

The Wifi and touchscreen are working on Ubuntu 14.10 now, here are the command line installation steps I used:

Wifi (a working internet connection is required for the first two steps below, I used a USB Wifi Adapter):

  sudo apt-get install build-essential linux-headers-generic git
  git clone https://github.com/codeTom/rtl8723bs.git
  cd rtl8723bs
  make
  sudo make install
  sudo depmod -a
  sudo modprobe r8723bs

Touchscreen:

  sudo apt-get install build-essential linux-headers-generic git (skip this if you have already done it above)
  git clone https://github.com/hadess/gt9xx.git
  cd gt9xx
  make
  sudo make install
  sudo depmod -a
  sudo modprobe goodix_backport

The touchscreen is currently only working in normal portrait mode, if I rotate the screen 90 degrees right or left in landscape mode, the cursor will not point where my finger is, I will look into a fix for this.

I have Ubuntu installed to the drive along with the Windows 10 Technical Preview as a dual boot. I have instructions for doing that in my review of the Stream 11 laptop which is similar since they both have the same eMMC drive: http://www.amazon.com/review/R28HR668I6LU8Y/ref=cm_cr_pr_cmt?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B00NSHLUBU

After Ubuntu is installed on the Stream 7, you may need to press F9 during boot up and select Ubuntu from the UEFI menu to get to the Grub Boot Menu.  If the boot hangs, select "Advanced Options for Ubuntu" and select recovery mode and it should fix it.

UPDATE January 14, 2015:

Michael (below) found the solution to the touchscreen problem where the touch input does not align with the display after rotating the screen.  Here are the commands to rotate it left:

  xrandr -o left
  xinput set-prop 'Goodix Capacitive TouchScreen' 'Coordinate Transformation Matrix' 0 -1 1 1 0 0 0 0 1

Here is rotating it right:

  xrandr -o right
  xinput set-prop 'Goodix Capacitive TouchScreen' 'Coordinate Transformation Matrix' 0 1 0 -1 0 1 0 0 1

More information is here: http://askubuntu.com/questions/405628/touchscreen-input-doesnt-rotate-lenovo-yoga-13-yoga-2-pro/405643#405643

Quick background on me. I'm an IT Manager and have been using computers since the Commodore 64. I'm familiar and capable around technology. I don't give up easily on tech. I like to have the latest and greatest and try new tech quite often. I'm also a huge fan of HP (it's all I buy at work and at home).

I really wanted to keep this device. However, as a couple of other reviewers have stated, the device works right out of the box but as soon as you apply Windows Updates it stops functioning, mostly due to wireless connection issues. I performed factory resets via the Change PC settings, Update and Recovery, Recovery, Remove everything and reset Windows. I did this three times. Each time the tablet worked OK until I ran Windows updates. It found 38 updates (all Windows 8.1 system updates, no drivers) and once it restarted the device would show it was connected to the wireless network but it couldn't communicate. I couldn't ping the router nor the router ping the device. HP's website does not have any updated drivers for these units yet. Windows Update did not find any updated drivers for the unit either. I checked RealTek for updated versions of the wireless driver but their site didn't have anything either. Other troubleshooting steps that I took: disabling IPv6, setting my router to only 2.4Ghz mode (unit does not support 5Ghz), using static IP settings and unfortunately the same results each time. From the many positive reviews I can only surmise that there is a small portion of these units that are affected by this.

While the device worked it was a good device. I was surprised by the performance of the quad-core Atom processor and only 1 gb of RAM. It ran quite well. It is only 32 bit so be aware of that. It is Windows 8.1 (not RT).

The unit comes with Office 365 Personal for a year which is a nice feature and almost worth the price of admission alone. The screen clarity was very good although the touch responsiveness was a little sluggish. There is no GPS and a single micro-USB port. The device does have a MicroSD slot that will support a 32Gb card (you have to remove the back cover to install it). Battery life seemed mediocre. When I was installing updates, resetting the device and reinstalling the updates and resetting again, it ran for about 2 hours and used about 60% of the charge. Keep in mind that to perform the system reset you have to have the device plugged in so it was getting charged at that time as well.

All in all, this would be a great device, especially for the $99 price! Unfortunately, there appears to be a problem with the units that coming from Amazon. HP doesn't post reviews for this unit so I couldn't check there for similar problems. The Microsoft Store site did not list any issues like this.

All in all, if you can get a good one you will probably like and want to keep it. I know I would have kept mine!

Thanks for reading.

On the positive side, the well resolved, bright screen with no problems with it's viewing angle. However the light sources (LEDs?) at the bottom of the tablet appear marginal uneaven, perhaps due to slight pressure in the screen housing - visible with a black display only.

The sound system plays reasonable well, however the internal speakers are bad compared to all of the tablets above. Using headphones, the sound appears slightly compromised with accompanying hissing noises from the CPU/electronics, depending on the computational load. But hearing louder music it does not bother me, only in more silent passages.

The battery consumption appears to be quite high during the operation.  I always feel that I would like to recharge as soon as possible. I never feel that way with my Nexus or Ipads. Positive is that the back cover can be removed and the battery gets visible. Although a label says it cannot be removed, I doubt this is not possible at all.

Computational speed is very ok! Even an XBOX racing game and many other games i tried out were just fine. ( I guess one of the  tablet's cool niche will be playing ?).

GPS ? I don't think it has one -  minus because I like tablets as off line mapping utilities

Camera - bad !! front and back - color tint, not very sensitive at all. Unusable to my taste.

I'm an avowed Mac fan, but I needed to run a few windows programs and was enticed by this tablet.  I was very surprised to find it become my go-to device.

First, it does something that no Apple or Android tablet can do - it runs the full version of iTunes.  The Kindle app is great.  You can install the free version of Spotify and play music on demand (without paying).  Same thing with Hulu.com.  Similar to Spotify, you can play anything on the Hulu site in explorer without paying.  It also includes a year of onedrive and Office 365.

The internal cameras are nothing to write home about, but they work well enough for Skype and video chat.

As for the size, it's a little bit shorter and a few mm thicker than a Nexus 7.  It reminds me of the first Kindle Fire in that it's not the thinnest tablet around.

But the biggest surprise is that the HP Stream had me rethink my planned iPad Air 2 purchase.  It won't replace it, but I now intend to buy a Surface Pro 3.  My iPad 3 still runs fine, but I feel that browsing and working is much more intuitive on a desktop OS.  (That said, it really makes the use case for a future iPad Air/Macbook Air hybrid.  I didn't think it would work but, in that case, props go to Microsoft.  And this is coming from somebody who has been all Mac for at least 6 years.

I nearly returned it, but read online that I should do a refresh of the OS - basically a reinstall.  It solved the problem.  (I'm not 100% convinced my unit was brand new, even though it was sold by Amazon and listed as such).

I was really looking forward to trying this tablet out. To date I'd had no exposure to Windows 8.1 or a dedicated Windows tablet. I have had a decent 10.1 inch Android tablet.

First are foremost, the elephant in the room... or rather, the mouse. This is a seven inch wide screen tablet. I have friends whose who online lives are conducted via five inch cell phone screens and they're happy with it. The screen on this tablet is nice. Don't get me wrong. I was able to stream from Amazon video in HD (720) and the video was crisp and clean. Images display well but, again, the screen is just seven inches. I can't imagine trying to be productive with something so small.

For a device with only one gig of RAM this runs Windows fairly well. I wws able to load several Windows programs including the Calibr eBook manager which took a little longer to convert eBooks between formats but did the job. I also loaded a legacy email and Usenet program that I've been using for a decade or longer. Along with directly installed programs I also downloaded a handful of apps from the very buggy Microsoft app store. The store worked less than 50% of the time while I was trying this tablet out. I at one point had to resort to switching to a local login account and then back to my Hotmail logi. It only took about an hour of reading web forums to find that solution to the Windows app store refusing to work.

Two problems I ran into were the sound which is from a single speaker hidden in a slot on one of the short sides of the tablet. If you want to listen to anything other than the default Window's beeps and tones you'll want to pair this with a blue tooth speaker or headphones. The speaker in this tablet is deplorable. The next problem I had was the tablet runs HOT. I was running a program designed for Windows 98, downloading and reading posts un Usenet and viewing a few posted vacation and astronomy images and I had to stop. The tablet was so hot it was uncomfortable to hold and I worried it might overheat and become damaged.

While I was impressed to see Windows running on a small tablet I was thoroughly unimpressed with Windows 8.1 the tile system is just terrible.

So, it has good video quality on a too small screen with horrible sound and a flaky app store to rely upon, though you can download and install normal Windows programs. I just wasn't that crazy about this tablet. And will definitely be sticking with Android and a much larger screen.

I purchased this for my wife as a tablet.  This is important.  She needed a tablet and not a PC.  She needed a tablet and not a laptop.  Although the HP Stream 7 runs the full version of Windows, it's running on tablet hardware.  Intel has finally started building x86 processors that have the battery life to compete with ARM-based tablets.  If this was available two years ago, we would never have seen Windows RT which was a stop-gap measure by Microsoft so that Windows would run on hardware with better than 3-4 hour battery life.  But I digress.  My point is that even though the Stream 7 is running a full version of Windows, IT'S STILL A TABLET and thus it should be judged as such and my review will reflect that.  So if you're a cheapo and need a full computer but are too cheap and think that this will be a viable replacement, it's not.  If you were thinking about getting a laptop and think this is a viable replacement, it's not.

I was originally looking at the 7 inch Galaxy Tab 4 for my wife.  We're not invested in the Apple ecosystem so overpriced i stuff was out of the picture.  But both of us share a Windows desktop and have Windows Phones so when I saw this sexy looking tablet for $99, I ran it by her and she said okay.  The main purpose of this device, like most tablets, is consumption.  Reading, watching, listening, browsing, and playing.  Minimal productive work can be done on this, or any other tablet.  So when I see people complaining about how small the text is, I have to shake my head.  If you need to be on the Windows desktop more than 30% of the time, buy a PC or a laptop.  As a tablet, you should be using this in the Modern UI (formerly called "Metro") most of the time.  The only reason I had to go to the desktop was to install various coupon printers for my wife. As a tablet, this is awesome.  Sure Windows 8.1 doesn't have billions of apps, but that's a temporary problem.  Once Windows 10 hits and everyone starts writing universal apps, the floodgates will open.

My only real knocks on the thing is it feels heavy in one hand, the battery life is kind of sorry and 1 GB of memory is meh.  I haven't run into any memory-related performance issues, but I would have liked to have 2 GB of memory.  But hey, it's a $99 tablet.  So other than those things, the HP Stream 7 is a solid tablet that stands toe-to-toe with the iPad and Galaxy Tab, but if you're in a pinch and need to do minor productive work on this, that's where it blows the traditional tablets out of the water.

The HP Stream 7 is one of the best gadget values I've ever seen. While it's not a perfect device, I can't help but love it due to its high bang for the buck ratio.

Disadvantages: No LED to indicate its charging when plugged in. No externally available micro-SD card slot, you have to power it down and open the back cover to access the micro-SD slot. The speaker is located where I tend to hold this type of device. It's a bit heavy and thick. I couldn't get iTunes 12 to recognize my iTunes music that I copied to a micro-SD card. Only has 1GB of RAM. However let's take into account that this device only costs $99.

Advantages: It has a 32GB SSD and storage can be expanded via a micro-SD card. It has a 64-bit quad-core Intel Atom CPU, (however it's running a 32-bit version of Windows 8.1), so it performs in a surprisingly snappy manner. It has a bright and fairly sharp screen. The plastic casing has a decent tactile feel to it and has a slight bevel around the edge, making it easier to hold. There's a Windows soft key on the right side to bring up the Windows 8 Start menu. There is no crapware installed on this device, shocking based on previous experience with HP products. The width of this device is perfect for me in terms of using the onscreen keyboard while in landscape mode. Streaming music and videos run without skipping a beat.

After installing all my apps it still has 15GB of free space. Given the variety of available free cloud services, there's really no good reason to store much data on a device of this class. Having said that  I installed a 32GB micro-SD card to store a sub-set of my MP3 collection and some movies. The Windows 8 Metro Music and Movies apps work surprisingly well and can playback media from my micro-SD card, so I ended up removing the iTunes software I installed. I was a bit skeptical of the Windows 8.1 GUI but after giving it a chance, I actually get it now and have gotten to like it. I'm a Windows and Linux system administrator, so I installed a SSH terminal, a RDP client, a VMware vSphere and a VPN client. I can actually use this tablet to manage my servers at work from anywhere I have wifi. Consider installing Google Chrome and enable the Windows 8 mode, MSIE 11 in the Metro mode is rather goofy in terms of usability. After setting up this device, I simply could not put it down. My work laptop has stayed in my laptop bag since I bought my HP Stream 7. Well done HP!

3 stars, this tablet has it all... the good, the bad, and the ugly.

The good:
1. Full version of windows 8.1 ($99)
2. Office 365 for it and another computer for a year ($70)
3. If you only use the Windows apps, they run well
4. The pixels look nice when watching videos
5. It fits in most of my back pockets.
6. It was $99
7. Bluetooth and wifi

The bad:
1. No LED on the front for use as a flash or flashlight
2. Nearly 1/2 of the "32GB" (29 actually) is used for Windows and office
3. Windows defender eats over 30% of the 1GB of ram
4. Battery like was about 4 hours until I had to plug it in
5. No GPS
6. The cameras are some of the worst

The Ugly:
1. the desktop mode is nearly useless due to the small fonts
2. No way to enlarge these items to make viability better
3. Touch screen nearly worthless and extremely frustrating, I have better control with my Samsung Galaxy S5 phone. Takes several times to select what I need to select
4. battery is non replaceable (if you are not tech savvy) even though the back case comes off
5. Micro SD slot is under the case, this makes no sense
6. No additional slots or ports besides mentioned, there are work arounds, but that will cost money and storage space.

Overall:
It is OK for the cost. I am somewhat disappointed as I am used to higher end phones, laptops, desktops, and not much with tablets. If I were in the market to upgrading a Windows 7 or needed Office 365, this would have been a great buy as the tablet would have been free (actually, you would save money by buying this and using the software codes instead). Unfortunately I needed neither. This is what it is, a $99 tablet running windows. Great as an ebook reader. Great if you don't have much experience with higher tech gadgets. And as some IT professionals have stated, great to do server things with, but I am in the middle between these.

My plan for this is to get a 64gb micro SD (even though the specs say up to 32) and hope it will work, if not, replace my phones micro with the 64 and put the 32 in this tablet. I plan to get the office 365 and run it on my laptop, then delete it off of the tablet and just run an older office on it. I have a case with BT keyboard on the way that I bought for $28 and it has an OTG adapter coming with it free. I also plan to get a cheap BT mouse for it so that I can hopefully use the actual desktop. I plan to use it as a media station for books and movies, and possibly an app here and there. I give it 3 stars, it isn't horrible, but I guess I wanted a little more. Next time I would spend an extra $100 to get something with more ram, a 8-10" display, and more functionality.

I hope my review helps othere that are looking at this tablet.
